TOP NEWS: Ryanair Buys Malta Air To Access Non EU Markets
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Buys Malta Air To Access Non EU Markets
Alliance News
June 11, 2019 Tuesday 12:42 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 160 words
Body
(Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Tuesday said it agreed to buy start up airline Malta Air to grow its Malta-
based fleet of six B737 aircraft and access non-EU markets, such as North Africa.
The Irish budget airline said it expects to complete the transaction by the end of June. 
Ryanair said it plans to transfer 200 Malta-based crew onto local contracts and create over 350 jobs by increasing 
its Malta based fleet to 10 aircraft within three years. 
"Malta Air will proudly fly the Maltese name and flag to over 60 destinations across Europe and North Africa as we 
look to grow our Maltese based fleet, routes, traffic and jobs over the next three years," said Ryanair Chief 
Executive Michael O'Leary.
The company did not disclose any financial details of the deal. 
Ryanair shares were trading 0.1% lower on Tuesday at EUR10.54 each in London.

TOP NEWS SUMMARY: BT To Close Offices In Over 270 UK Locations
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: BT To Close Offices In Over 270 UK Locations
Alliance News
June 5, 2019 Wednesday 10:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 1379 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following is a summary of top news stories Wednesday.
----------
COMPANIES
----------
BT Group said it will close around 270 offices as it looks to consolidate its operations into just 30 locations across 
the country. The FTSE 100-listed telecommunications firm was making the move as part of its "Better Workplace" 
programme announced in May 2018. Ultimately, this will see the former state-owned monopoly consolidate its more 
than 300 current locations to just around 30. The programme is part of a broader plan to cut as many as 13,000 
back office and middle management jobs and a three-year cost reduction of GBP1.5 billion. These consolidated 
sites will contain "modern, future-fit buildings, including corporate offices, contact centres and specialist sites", the 
firm explained. The process is expected to be completed by 2023. 
----------
Provident Financial said the collapse of Non-Standard Finance's hostile GBP1.1 billion takeover for the company 
was "in the best interest of shareholders". Responding to a statement from lender NSF, stating that it would "lapse" 
the offer after discussions with the UK regulators, Provident said it "greatly regrets the unnecessary distraction, cost 
and impact of the uncertainty" caused by the bid. NFS's bid for its bigger London-listed home credit rival collapsed 
after the UK financial regulator blocked the deal on Tuesday. NSF said it would "lapse" the offer following 
discussions with the regulatory authorities as it had received a low level of acceptances by Wednesday's deadline 
to declare the offer bid wholly unconditional. As at Wednesday, NFS had received acceptances from around 54% of 
Provident investors. 
----------
Aviva said Chief Financial Officer Tom Stoddard will step down from his role and from the FTSE 100 insurer's board 
from the end of June. Stoddard - CFO since 2014 - will be replaced by Aviva UK Insurance CFO Jason Windsor on 
an interim basis, with Stoddard remaining at Aviva until the end of 2019 in order to "support an orderly transition." 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: BT To Close Offices In Over 270 UK Locations
Windsor has been at Aviva since 2010 and has "extensive" experience of the firm after serving in a number of 
different senior roles. 
----------
Ryanair Holdings said its traffic rose 13% in May as the company carried 14.1 million passengers in the month. In 
the same month of 2018, the Irish budget airline transported 12.5 million passengers. Excluding the contribution of 
Austrian airline Lauda, which Ryanair acquired in December, the airline's traffic was up 8% to 13.5 million 
customers. On a rolling annual basis, Ryanair's traffic was up 10% in May to 144.9 million passengers from 132.1 
million a year prior. In May, Ryanair operated almost 78,000 scheduled flights. 
----------
Workspace Group said it delivered "impressive" growth in its most recently ended financial year, on the back of 
which it increased its dividend. The office space provider said its pretax profit declined by 19% in the year to the 
end of March to GBP137.3 million from GBP170.4 million reported a year ago, due to reduced income from 
disposals and lower uplift in property valuation. Trading profit, however, rose by 19% to GBP72.4 million from 
GBP60.7 million year-on-year. The trading profit is net rental income, less administrative expenses and net finance 
costs. The company declared a final dividend of 22.26 pence a share, taking the total payout for the year to 32.87p, 
up 20% from 27.39p paid the year before. 
----------
MARKETS
----------
London shares were higher following a strong close in the US overnight after dovish comments from the Federal 
Reserve. In the FTSE 250, Provident was the best performer, up 17%. The pound was up against the dollar 
following positive UK services PMI data. Wall Street was pointed to a higher open. 
----------
FTSE 100: up 0.5% at 7,252.08
FTSE 250: up 0.8% at 19,162.71
AIM ALL-SHARE: up 0.3% at 945.07
GBP: up at USD1.2712 (USD1.2675)
EUR: up at USD1.1280 (USD1.1240)
GOLD: up at USD1,336.10 per ounce (USD1,321.10)
OIL (Brent): firm at USD61.84 a barrel (USD61.78)
(changes since previous London equities close)
----------
ECONOMICS AND GENERAL
----------
Amid growing concerns escalating global trade tensions could spark a recession, US Federal Reserve Chairman 
Jerome Powell has pledged the central bank will take appropriate actions to sustain the US, economic expansion. 
Powell mentioned recent developments involving trade negotiations and other matters in opening remarks at a 
Chicago Fed conference on Tuesday, acknowledging that the Fed does not know how or when these issues will be 
resolved. "We are closely monitoring the implications of these developments for the US economic outlook and, as 
always, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near our 
symmetric 2% objective," Powell said. The rest of Powell's speech focused on longer-run issues, but the Fed chief's 
initial comments generated optimism about a potential interest rate cut and spurred a rally on Wall Street. Powell's 
comments come after St Louis Fed President James Bullard suggested in a speech on Monday that an interest rate 
cut "may be warranted soon" due in part to escalating global trade tensions.
----------
The World Bank downgraded its global growth outlook, citing subdued investment and risks from escalating trade 
tensions. Global growth is forecast to slow to 2.6% this year, reflecting weaker-than-expected trade and investment, 
the bank said in its semi-annual report. The 2019 growth outlook was revised down from 2.9%. Annual economic 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: BT To Close Offices In Over 270 UK Locations
growth is projected to gradually rise back to 2.8% by 2021, predicated on continued benign global financing 
conditions and a modest recovery in emerging market and developing economies.
----------
Activity in the dominant UK services sector accelerated sharply in the month of May, the latest survey report from 
IHS Markit showed. IHS Markit/CIPS UK services purchasing managers' index rose to 51.0 in May from 50.4 in 
April. This comfortably beat the consensus estimate of 50.6, as compiled by FXStreet. Any reading above 50.0 
indicates expansion in the sector.
----------
Eurozone private sector growth remained sluggish in May, despite an improvement on the earlier flash reading 
sending the pace to a three month high as the service sector expanded at a "solid" rate. Data from IHS Markit 
released on Wednesday showed the eurozone composite purchasing managers' index edged up to 51.8 points in 
May from 51.5 points in April. The final May print also represented an improvement on the flash reading of 51.6 
points. IHS Markit explained the growth in May was driven by the services sector. The eurozone services PMI in 
May read 52.9 points, up from 52.8 in April, and ahead of the 52.5 points flash estimate for May. 
----------
The Irish unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 4.4% in May from 4.6% in April and 5.9% in May 2018, 
according a report by the Central Statistics Office. Industrial production rose 3.5% in April from March and was up 
7.1% on a year before, the CSO said.
----------
China registered a "modest" expansion in business during May, Caixin showed, but growth has slowed. The 
Chinese Services Business Activity Index fell to 52.7 in May, a three-month low, from 54.5 in April. A figure over 50 
means expansion. This shows that services sector activity did expand in May, but the rate eased somewhat from 
April. The slower growth in the services sector pushed down the composite output index for May to 51.5 from 52.7 
in April, also a three-month low. 
----------
Financial regulators in the UK and the Netherlands signed a new closer partnership as Brexit raised additional 
cooperation and oversight needs for the two countries. The UK Financial Conduct Authority said it had signed the 
agreement to formalise the closer partnership with the Dutch Authority for the Financial Markets in order to "protect 
and enhance the integrity and stability of both countries financial systems." The FCA explained that since the UK 
voted to leave the European Union in 2016 - a process which is still being finalised - "several" financial institutions 
operating in both the UK and Netherlands have applied for a licence to operate in both countries. 
----------

LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Non-Standard Finance Deal For Provident Off
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Non-Standard Finance Deal For Provident Off
Alliance News
June 5, 2019 Wednesday 06:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1002 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are set to open higher on Wednesday, following onfrom sharp 
gains seen on Wall Street after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell suggested the US central bank could lower 
interest rates.
In London, Non-Standard Finance's hostile takeover of larger doorstep lending rival Provident Financial lapsed. 
FTSE 100-listed Aviva's chief financial officer has decided to step down, while Workspace reported a sharp rise in 
rental income. 
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 is set to open 7.01 points higher at 7,221.30. The blue chip index closed up 29.49 
points, or 0.4%, at 7,214.29 on Tuesday.
Non-Standard Finance's hostile GBP1.1 billion takeover for Provident Financial collapsed after the UK financial 
regulator blocked the deal on Tuesday.
Non-Standard Finance said it would "lapse" the offer following discussions with regulatory authorities as it had 
received a low level of acceptances by Wednesday deadline to declare the offer bid wholly unconditional. As at 
Wednesday, Non-Standard Finance had received acceptances from around 54% of Provident investors. 
Non-Standard Finance explained that while it remains appropriately capitalised, due to the low level of acceptances 
received, "the enlarged Non-Standard Finance group would not have sufficient regulatory capital on a consolidated 
basis at completion due to the expected level of minority interests at that point".
John van Kuffeler, Non-Standard Finance's group chief executive said: "I am very disappointed that despite our 
best efforts customers, employees and shareholders will not now benefit from our transformation plan to build a 
brighter future by combining Provident with Non-Standard Finance."
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Non-Standard Finance Deal For Provident Off
Aviva said CFO Tom Stoddard will be stepping down at the end of June. Aviva said Stoddard will remain with the 
company until the end of 2019 to "support an orderly transition". 
Current Aviva UK Insurance CFO Jason Windsor has been appointed interim CFO for the group.
Ryanair said its May traffic was up 13% year-on-year to 14.1 million customers. The budget airline operated 78,000 
scheduled flights in May. 
Office space rental firm Workspace saw a sharp fall in pretax profit in financial 2019 due to a lower year-on-year 
valuation increase and lower disposals profits compared to the year before. 
In the twelve months to March 31, Workspace reported pretax profit of GBP137.3 million, down from GBP170.4 
million. The company's trading profit increased 19%, however, to GBP72.4 million.
Workspace hiked its full year dividend 20% to 32.87 pence.
Card Factory said its first-quarter total sales were up 6.4% on a year before, with like-for-like sales in the three 
months to April 30 up 2.3%.
Card Factory said its performance in the first quarter "represents an encouraging start to the year". The company's 
expectations for the full year remain unchanged.
Go-Ahead said it has appointed Elodie Brian as chief financial officer on a permanent basis. Brian has been the 
firm's interim CFO since December. 
Speaking at the motoring association's AGM, AA said its trading in the period is in line with expectations and 
remains "well positioned" to meet its medium-term growth targets to financial 2023. AA also said it is "well 
positioned" to see Ebitda growth in financial 2020.
AA's financial year ends January 31.
Fed Chair Powell pledged the central bank will take appropriate actions to sustain the US economic expansion. 
Powell mentioned recent developments involving trade negotiations and other matters in opening remarks at a 
Chicago Fed conference on Tuesday, acknowledging that the Fed does not know how or when these issues will be 
resolved.
"We are closely monitoring the implications of these developments for the US economic outlook and, as always, we 
will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near our symmetric 2% 
objective," Powell said.
The rest of Powell's speech focused on longer-run issues, but the Fed chief's initial comments generated optimism 
about a potential interest rate cut and spurred a rally on Wall Street.
Powell's comments come after St Louis Fed President James Bullard suggested in a speech on Monday that an 
interest rate cut "may be warranted soon" due in part to escalating global trade tensions.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ending up 2.1%, the S&P 500 up 2.1% and Nasdaq Composite up 2.7%.
In Asia on Wednesday, the Japanese Nikkei 225 closed up 1.8%. In China, the Shanghai Composite is up 0.1%, 
and the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong is up 0.5%.
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Non-Standard Finance Deal For Provident Off
Sterling was quoted at USD1.2706 early Wednesday, higher than USD1.2675 at the London equities close on 
Wednesday.
US President Donald Trump on Tuesday promised a "phenomenal" trade deal between the UK and US on his 
second day of a three-day state visit to the UK. "As the UK makes preparations to exit the EU, the US is committed 
to a phenomenal trade deal between the US and the UK," Trump said. "There is tremendous potential in that trade 
deal, I say probably two and even three times what we're doing right now."
The economic events calendar on Wednesday has Markit services PMI readings from France, Germany, the 
Eurozone and the UK at 0850 BST, 0855 BST, 0900 BST and 0930 BST, respectively.
Later in the day, there is Eurozone producer price index at 1000 BST and US Markit PMI reading at 1445 BST.
Already out, China's private sector activity growth moderated to a three-month low in May partly driven by softer 
rise in services activity, survey results published by IHS Markit revealed.
The Caixin composite output index fell to 51.5 in May from 52.7 in April. Nonetheless, the score remained above 
50.0 for the thirty-ninth consecutive month, suggesting continuing expansion in the sector.
The services Purchasing Managers' Index dropped to a 3-month low of 52.7 in May from 54.5 in April. However, the 
score was consistent with a robust rise in output amid firm client demand.

IN THE KNOW: JPMorgan Thinks IAG 's Shareholder Return Can Rise Further
IN THE KNOW: JPMorgan Thinks IAG's Shareholder Return Can Rise Further
Alliance News
June 5, 2019 Wednesday 12:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Positive
Length: 618 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - JPMorgan started coverage on International Consolidated Airlines Group with a Buy 
rating and said the airline operator diversified portfolio and high profit margins can facilitate strong returns for 
shareholders. 
The US bank placed a EUR8.35 price target on the stock. IAG shares were up 2.1% at 472.80 pence on 
Wednesday. 
IAG is a Spanish registered company with shares traded on the London and Madrid stock exchanges and was born 
following the merger between British Airways and Iberia, the flag carrier airlines of the UK and Spain respectively.
IAG is not an airline itself, rather operates as an owner of a portfolio of airlines, which also includes Ireland's Aer 
Lingus and Spain's low cost carrier Vueling. 
The company is headquartered in London and employs only 100 people. IAG emphasises that it is not merely a 
holding company, and that its role is to extract synergies across its airlines and to add value to each of them.
IAG shares are 30% lower so far in 2019, having warned shareholders that profits for the year will be flat. 
Moreover, airlines have cited Brexit uncertainty, the general weakness of the European economy, and a competitive 
environment in Germany and Austria, where multiple airlines are still fighting to grow market share after the 
collapse of Air Berlin in August 2017. The two biggest European low cost airlines Ryanair and easyJet have 
significantly lowered profit guidance, in part due to weaker than expected fares.
JPMorgan's David Perry and Andrew Fincher highlighted that many investors are concerned that IAG's earnings 
growth would be at risk should a recession occur if the UK crashes out of the European Union without a deal.
IN THE KNOW: JPMorgan Thinks IAG 's Shareholder Return Can Rise Further
"A hard Brexit would certainly be challenging. First, UK shareholders would likely lose voting rights and may be 
forced to sell their shares. Second, if the pound fell 10% versus the dollar and the euro, it could take 20% off 
earnings per share via transaction and translation impacts. However, we do not believe a hard Brexit would have a 
material impact on trans-Atlantic travel (where IAG is most profitable)," the pair said. 
The analysts also believe IAG's valuation is mispriced compared to peers easyJet and Ryanair.
"We believe IAG is materially mispriced against Ryanair and easyJet. IAG's earnings befrore interest and tax 
margin and return on capital employed are now as good as Ryanair and much better than those of easyJet. But 
relative to these two low cost carriers, IAG is trading on 55% to 65% price to earnings discount and a 30% to 45% 
EV/EBIT discount," the pair noted. 
Perry and Fincher said one of IAG's key strategies is to acquire entire airlines or assets from failing airlines focused 
in Europe, but there are concerns among investors that the company company can make an "overpriced" 
acquisition. 
"IAG says it is willing to issue equity for the right deal. However, it also acknowledges that opportunities for M&A 
are quite rare and currently it has few options. We suspect IAG's best opportunity to make meaningful acquisitions 
will come when/if the European airline industry enters its next major downturn," the analysts said. 
Perry and Fincher also highlighted the company's strong cash returns as a positive, with a special dividend 
payment due in July and believe there is scope for this to continue. 
"We also believe investors are overlooking IAG's attractions: high pretax profit margins; a diversified portfolio that 
should mean more resilient earnings than in the past; strong market positions; a strong balance sheet; and rising 
cash returns to shareholders," the pair added. 
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: June 5, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Holdings Agrees Pay Deal With Belgian -Based Cabin Crew
Ryanair Holdings Agrees Pay Deal With Belgian-Based Cabin Crew
Alliance News
June 4, 2019 Tuesday 10:37 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 76 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Tuesday said it reached a pay and rostering agreement with 
its cabin crew based in Belgium.
The Irish budget airline said the three-year deal was negotiated with the unions CNE-CSC and LBC-NVK, with a 
74% majority of members approving it. 
Ryanair shares were trading 2.5% higher at EUR10.32 pence each. 
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.

IN THE KNOW: Analysts Cut Forecasts But Ryanair Still Top Airline Pick
IN THE KNOW: Analysts Cut Forecasts But Ryanair Still Top Airline Pick
Alliance News
May 29, 2019 Wednesday 12:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 479 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Both Liberum and UBS remained bullish on Ryanair, despite the budget airline's weak 
annual results and a challenging market backdrop, though both downgraded their forecasts. 
Ryanair shares were down 1.4% at EUR10.48 on Wednesday, having shed 37% compared to this time a year ago.
UBS said it was disappointed by Ryanair's annual results and, in addition, the outlook for the year ahead was 
weaker than expected despite easy comparatives. 
For the financial year ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 41% 
from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, which Ryanair 
snapped up in December.
Late Austrian entrepreneur and former Formula One champion Niki Lauda originally founded the airline under the 
name Niki in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011. Following Air Berlin's bankruptcy, he bought it back in 
2018 and re-established it as Laudamotion with the help of London-listed Thomas Cook.
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.69 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue. 
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," Ryanair commented alongside its results.
UBS downgraded its 2020 earnings per share forecast by 8% to EUR0.92 - though still above consensus at 
EUR0.87 - but said it thinks average fares should rise 1%, which would be at the top end of Ryanair's guided range. 
The Swiss bank said it thinks the fare environment should improve over the summer given the benign capacity 
outlook. 
IN THE KNOW: Analysts Cut Forecasts But Ryanair Still Top Airline Pick
UBS cut its price target on the stock to EUR14.45 from EUR15.25, but kept its Buy rating.
Liberum similarly maintained its Buy recommendation on the stock, though lowered its target to EUR12.50 from 
EUR14.50.
"The airline industry faces numerous short-term headwinds. The demand outlook is potentially softening, fuel prices 
remain high and Brexit uncertainty persists. However, Ryanair's long-term fundamentals remain intact and 
attractive, with a low cost base, market leadership, a robust balance sheet and strong cash generation," argued 
Liberum.
The broker cut its 2020 profit after tax forecast to EUR844 to match Ryanair's new guidance range, from EUR1.03 
billion predicted previously by Liberum, and noted that while the industry capacity environment is more supportive 
than last summer, macroeconomic uncertainty is weighing on demand.
Despite this, Ryanair remains Europe's "long-term winner" the broker maintained. 
Tougher maker conditions should actually act as a boon to Ryanair in the short term, as it weeds out weaker 
competitors and aids consolidation, Liberum added.
By Lucy Heming; lucyheming@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 29, 2019
End of Document

CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Struggle, Retail Recovers
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Struggle, Retail Recovers
Alliance News
May 24, 2019 Friday 11:38 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 763 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - News in the consumer services sector this week continued to highlight struggles in the 
travel sector, with Irish budget airline Ryanair reporting a significant fall in profit. 
Meanwhile, results from retailers Marks & Spencer and B&M European Value Retail showed improved 
performances in the retail sector, as both reported a profit jump.
Ryanair started the week posting a 41% drop in annual pretax profit to EUR948.1 million due to higher oil prices, up 
23% in the year, and lower fares in a competitive market. Group revenue, for the year to march 31, rose 6% to 
EUR7.69 billion.
Furthermore, the low-cost airline warned of "zero" visibility on its results beyond the next few months.
Ryanair was not the only struggling airline in a year which saw a number of EU airlines failing including Primera, 
Sky Works and WOW. Flybe was sold, while both Alitalia and Thomas Cook's airline are currently for sale.
With regards to the sale of its airline, travel operator Thomas Cook on Thursday confirmed receiving an offer from 
private equity firm Triton Partners for its Nordic operations.
The travel company's Nordic business comprises of its tour operator and airline in Norway, Sweden, Finland and 
Denmark.
Thomas Cook said it was evaluating the offer alongside its ongoing strategic review of its group airline. The group 
said it has so far received multiple bids for parts and the whole of the airline business.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Struggle, Retail Recovers
Also on Thursday, Thomas Cook received less positive news, with Fitch, S&P and Moody's downgrading the stock 
on concerns of weak trading and further deterioration.
Meanwhile, retailers seemed to be having a better time. 
On Wednesday, homeware, clothing and food retailer Marks & Spencer Group reported a moderate decline in 
revenue but double-digit profit growth in its recently-ended financial year to March.
M&S said pretax profit rose 27% to GBP84.6 million despite revenue falling 3.0% to GBP10.38 billion. This was 
achieved thanks to the ongoing transformation programme launched by the company with the aim of delivering cost 
savings and growing the business. 
However, looking ahead M&S said it expects net store closures to reduce sales by 1% in its UK Food division, while 
in the UK Clothing & Home unit, sales are anticipated to fall by 3% in the new year.
On Thursday, discount homewares retailer B&M European Value Retail also reported a positive annual 
performance with both revenue and profit increasing on the prior year.
For the year ended March 30, B&M posted pretax profit up 8.7% to GBP249.4 million and revenue increased 17% 
to GBP3.48 billion. UK B&M store fascia revenue rose 8.7%, 0.7% on a like-for-like basis.
Furthermore, reflecting the positive results, B&M upped its total payout 5.7% to 7.6 pence.
Looking ahead, the company reported a "pleasing start" to the first quarter of financial 2020, with mid-single digit 
like-for-like growth in B&M UK fascia stores.
Meanwhile on Friday, struggling baby products retailer Mothercare also published improved results as the effects of 
its restructuring programme slashed costs by 29%. 
This resulted in Mothercare's pretax loss narrowing to GBP66.6 million for the year to March 30, compared to the 
GBP94.0 million loss reported the year earlier.
However, revenue also declined by 12% to GBP513.8 million from GBP580.6 million the year before, due to the 
chain's UK store closure programme. 
"We have achieved a huge amount this year, refinancing, restructuring and reorganising Mothercare to ensure a 
sustainable future for the business," said Chief Executive Mark Newton-Jones. "Whilst this major restructuring 
activity has resulted in significant headline losses for the year, the business is now on a sounder financial footing." 
Lastly, FTSE 250 stationery & books retailer WH Smith on Tuesday announced its chief executive's departure, as 
sales in the third quarter of the year improved significantly. 
After 15 years with WH Smith, six of which as CEO, Stephen Clarke will step down from the board at the end of 
October, as he plans to "take a break".
Carl Cowling, managing director of the company's High Street business, will take over the role of CEO from 
November 1.
On the same day, reflecting improvements in the retail sector, WH Smith reported a 15% sales increase, 1% on a 
like-for-like basis in the 11-week period from March 1 to May 18.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Struggle, Retail Recovers
The company's Travel unit saw sales up 26% while the High Street business continued to experience struggles with 
sales down by 1%.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 24, 2019
End of Document
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Faces Higher Costs, Less Demand And Brexit - HSBC
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Faces Higher Costs, Less Demand And Brexit - 
HSBC
Alliance News
May 22, 2019 Wednesday 12:13 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 791 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - HSBC downgraded Ryanair Holdings to Reduce from Hold saying challenges are piling 
up for the Irish airline, including Brexit, weakening European economies, reduced travel demand, and higher costs. 
The bank cut its price target to EUR9.40 from EUR12.00. Ryanair shares were down 3.1% at EUR10.13 on 
Wednesday in London.
Ryanair on Monday reported a significant fall in profit in a year which saw many EU airlines struggle due to higher 
oil prices and lower fares in a competitive market, and warned of "zero" visibility on its results beyond the next few 
months.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the budget carrier reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 41% 
from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's Austrian 
airline established by Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December. The former Formula 1 racing champion 
died earlier this week.
HSBC's Andrew Lobbenberg and Achal Kumar said evidence from the market is that air passenger demand has not 
recovered. The pair pointed to travel demand remaining weak, with airlines and tour operators securing bookings 
with price incentives. 
"We do not think the situation will change for the important late summer bookings, since we will likely only be 
getting closer to the new October Brexit deadline. Away from the UK, we think economic growth continues to slow 
with political uncertainty in Italy and with global trade concerns in Germany," Lobbenberg and Kumar said. 
In the UK, political uncertainty relating to Brexit has hurt demand for air travel, with low-cost carriers, as well as tour 
operators feeling the effects. The companies continue to fill their UK-based aircraft; however weaker consumer 
demand equates to weaker unit revenue.
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Faces Higher Costs, Less Demand And Brexit - HSBC
"In the event of a no-deal Brexit, Ryanair would face significant ownership and control issues. Its UK ownership 
would not count towards its EU ownership count, leaving it some 20%, we estimate, short of majority EU ownership 
and control, which is required to sustain its Irish Air Operators Certificate. Ryanair would also be highly vulnerable 
to weak consumer demand for UK outbound and also UK inbound travel," the analysts said. 
With regards to Boeing 737 Max aircraft, which was grounded following two deadly accidents, Ryanair said it has 
delayed the delivery of its first five 737 Max jets to Winter 2019. 
Lobbenberg and Kumar said delay in delivery of the more efficient aircraft will weigh slightly on Ryanair's unit costs, 
but the main threat lies in the uncertainty from planning and crewing.
"We also think there is a risk that any public difference of opinions among aviation regulators around the world 
could bring the Max aircraft into the headlines once again. This could, at least in the first instance, create some 
consumer reluctance to fly the aircraft, which could weigh on Ryanair's unit revenues," the pair said. 
The analysts also think fleet growth at Lauda is weighing on the stock. At Lauda, Ryanair plans to grow the fleet 
from 10 aircraft in summer 2018, to 23 aircraft in summer 2019 and 35 in summer 2020.
"Lauda's profitability is weak; its Airbus aircraft leased from the market will not have the ownership cost advantage 
of Ryanair’s legacy 737NG fleet. Lauda is focussing its growth in Vienna which is suffering acute excess capacity, 
with April 2019 traffic growing 26%. This is not sustainable, in our view," the pair added. 
Also reflecting the difficult times in the airline industry, Ryanair's rival easyJet on Friday last week reported a sharp 
widening to its interim loss also due to an increase in fuel costs. 
HSBC reiterated its Hold rating on easyJet and 1,100p price target on the stock. easyJet was down 4.2% at 
943.20p Wednesday.
The analysts said easyJet is in a "surprisingly good place", with improved cost guidance particularly encouraging, 
while consumer and labour engagement scores are also strong.
"We have high regard for the company's strategic position within the industry and the stock has fallen 20% in the 
last month. It is only 10% above its five year low dating from June 2016 in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Why are 
we not buyers? Given the multiple macro challenges, our 2019 pretax profit estimate sits below what was the 
company-sourced running consensus into interim results, which was endorsed by the company as a sensible 
forecast for year profits," the pair said of easyJet. 
"We are not at all confident that the company has navigated its last profit warning. Airline share prices do trade in 
line with earnings momentum and we are unsure we have passed any inflection point."
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 22, 2019
End of Document
BROKER RATINGS SUMMARY: JPMorgan Downgrades Ryanair To Neutral

TOP NEWS: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% On Higher Fuel Costs
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% On Higher Fuel Costs
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 05:57 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 325 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday reported a significant fall in its annual profit due to 
increased fuel, airport and staff costs.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 
41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's 
Austrian airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December. 
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.69 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue. 
Fuel & oil costs rose 23% to EUR2.42 billion from EUR1.90 billion, staff costs increased 28% to EUR945.0 million 
from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.
"As previously guided, Ryanair, excluding Lauda, reports a full year after tax profit of EUR1.02 billion. Short-haul 
capacity growth and the absence of Easter in the fourth quarter led to a 6% fare decline, which stimulated 7% traffic 
growth to over 139 million," Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary commented.
During the year, Ryanair saw a 7% increase in traffic - meaning the number of passengers carries - to 139.1 million 
from 130.3 million. 
Load factor - a key measure for the airline industry - rose 1% to 96%. 
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in financial 2020 to 153 million passengers. However, assuming 
revenue per pax growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for  broadly flat group profit, including Lauda. This will range from 
EUR750 million if RPP rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if RPP rises 4%. 
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% On Higher Fuel Costs
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through Summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," the company added.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 20, 2019
End of Document
EXTRA: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% Amid Tough Year For Airlines
EXTRA: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% Amid Tough Year For Airlines
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 08:14 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 572 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday reported a significant fall in profit in a year which saw 
many EU airlines struggle due to higher oil prices and lower fares in a competitive market, and it warned of "zero" 
visibility on its results beyond the next few months.
More positively, Ryanair approved a EUR700 million share buyback which will commence later this week and run 
for the next 9 to 12 months. 
The stock was down 5.7% in London at EUR10.18 on Monday morning, leading a wider decline among travel 
stocks.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 
41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's 
Austrian airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December. 
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.69 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue. 
Fuel & oil costs rose 23% to EUR2.42 billion from EUR1.90 billion, staff costs increased 28% to EUR945.0 million 
from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.
"As previously guided, Ryanair, excluding Lauda, reports a full year after tax profit of EUR1.02 billion. Short-haul 
capacity growth and the absence of Easter in the fourth quarter led to a 6% fare decline, which stimulated 7% traffic 
growth to over 139 million," Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary commented.
During the year, Ryanair saw a 7% increase in traffic - meaning the number of passengers carried - to 139.1 million 
from 130.3 million. 
EXTRA: Ryanair Annual Profit Drops 40% Amid Tough Year For Airlines
Load factor - a key measure for the airline industry - rose by one percentage point to 96%. 
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in financial 2020 to 153 million passengers. However, assuming 
revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit, including Lauda. This will range 
from EUR750 million if RPP rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if RPP rises 4%. 
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through Summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," the company added.
With regards to Boeing 737 Max aircraft, which was grounded following two deadly accidents, Ryanair said it has 
delayed the delivery of its first five 737 Max jets to Winter 2019. 
"We continue to have utmost confidence in these aircraft which have 4% more seats, are 16% more fuel efficient 
and generate 40% lower noise emissions," Ryanair said. 
The delayed arrival however, will mean that the company will not see any meaningful cost benefit from the new jets 
until financial 2021.
Ryanair also noted that during the past year a number of EU airlines failed including Primera, Sky Works and 
WOW. Flybe was sold, while both Alitalia and Thomas Cook airline are currently for sale.
Also reflecting the difficult times in the airline industry, Ryanair rival easyJet PLC on Friday last week reported a 
sharp widening to its interim loss also due to an increase in fuel costs. 
In the six months to March 31, easyJet's pretax loss came in at GBP272 million compared to GBP68 million 
reported for the same period a year earlier. Revenue increased 7.3% to GBP2.34 billion in the period.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com

Load-Date: May 20, 2019
End of Document
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Called "Long-Term Winner" Despite Weak Guidance
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Called "Long-Term Winner" Despite Weak Guidance
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 08:41 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Positive
Length: 390 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Liberum described Ryanair's guidance as "disappointing", with investors also likely to 
be disheartened by persistent non-fuel unit cost inflation. 
Shares in the budget airline were down 4.9% at EUR10.28 on Monday. Liberum kept its Buy rating and a EUR14.50 
price target on the stock.
For the financial year ended March 31, the Irish carrier reported a pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 41% from 
EUR1.61 billion the year prior. 
Operating profit of EUR1.19 billion, down 29% year-on-year, was below consensus of EUR1.21 billion but above 
Liberum's estimate of EUR1.18 billion.
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.56 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue. However, this was below both Liberum's revenue expectation of EUR7.59 billion and consensus of 
EUR7.69 billion. 
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in its recently commenced financial year to 153 million 
passengers. However, assuming revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit, 
including Lauda. 
This will range from EUR750 million if revenue per passenger rises 2%, and up to EUR950 million if revenue per 
passenger rises 4%. 
In addition, non-fuel unit costs are set to rise by 2% due to a stronger pound, Lauda costs, and delays to the 
delivery of new Boeing 737 MAX aircraft.
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Called "Long-Term Winner" Despite Weak Guidance
Liberum deemed this guidance "disappointing" relative to consensus, which had lay above the higher end of 
Ryanair's outlook at around EUR977 million. 
"While management's caution on average fares is typical, especially at this stage of the year, there seems to be 
clear reliance upon strong ancillary revenue to deliver overall improvements in revenue per passenger," said 
Liberum. "There may also be disappointment at non-fuel unit cost inflation persisting."
Nonetheless, the broker said Ryanair remains the "long-term winner" in the European airline space. 
A tougher market in the short-term will benefit Ryanair in the long-term as the operating environment "clears out" 
weaker competitors and aids consolidation. 
Ryanair trades on a price to earnings ratio of 11.9 times, which Liberum said is "reasonable" even allowing for likely 
consensus downgrades following Monday's results. 
By Lucy Heming; lucyheming@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 20, 2019
End of Document
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Warns Of "Zero Visibility" Beyond Few Months
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Warns Of "Zero Visibility" Beyond Few Months
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 07:08 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 1845 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings on Monday reported a significant fall in annual profit due to increased 
fuel, airport and staff costs, and it said it has "zero" visibility on its likely results beyond the first half of the current 
year.
More positively, Ryanair announced a EUR700 million share buyback to run over the next 9 to 12 months.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 
41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's 
Austrian airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December.
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.69 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue.
Fuel & oil costs rose 23% to EUR2.42 billion from EUR1.90 billion, staff costs increased 28% to EUR945.0 million 
from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.
"As previously guided, Ryanair, excluding Lauda, reports a full year after tax profit of EUR1.02 billion. Short-haul 
capacity growth and the absence of Easter in the fourth quarter led to a 6% fare decline, which stimulated 7% traffic 
growth to over 139 million," Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary commented.
During the year, Ryanair saw a 7% increase in traffic - meaning the number of passengers carries - to 139.1 million 
from 130.3 million. Load factor - a key measure for the airline industry - rose by one point to 96%.
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Warns Of "Zero Visibility" Beyond Few Months
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in financial 2020 to 153 million passengers. However, assuming 
revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit, including Lauda. This will range 
from EUR750 million if RPP rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if RPP rises 4%.
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through Summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," the company added.
Ryanair shares were down 5.6% in early dealings Monday.

UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to begin discussions with senior ministers on her proposed new "bold offer" 
to members of Parliament in a final attempt to get her Brexit deal through Parliament. The weekly meeting of the 
Cabinet on Tuesday is expected to sign off on a package of measures to be included in the forthcoming Withdrawal 
Agreement Bill aimed at winning cross-party support. However there was widespread scepticism at Westminster 
that it will fare any better than her three previous failed attempts to get the Commons to pass the deal. It comes at 
the start of what looks likely to be another torrid week for the prime minister with the Conservatives braced for a 
hammering at the hands of Nigel Farage's Brexit Party in the European elections on Thursday.

house hunters in some areas now face record high amounts being demanded by sellers. Across Britain, the 
average asking price is GBP308,290 – GBP2,841 or 0.9% higher than in April, according to the figures from 
Rightmove. The website, whose records go back over a decade, said Wales, the Midlands and the North West of 
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Warns Of "Zero Visibility" Beyond Few Months

highs.

Japan's gross domestic product climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.5% on quarter in the first quarter of 2019, the 
Cabinet Office said in a preliminary reading. That beat forecasts for a fall 0.1% and was up from the downwardly 
revised 0.4% gain in the three months prior, which was originally reported as 0.5%. On an annualized yearly basis, 
GDP was up 2.1% - again exceeding expectations for a fall of 0.2% following the downwardly revised 1.6% gain in 
the previous three months - originally 1.9%.

US President Donald Trump vowed Sunday to deny Tehran nuclear weapons just hours after threatening it would 
"be the official end of Iran" when the country's Revolutionary Guard said it was not afraid of war. "I will not let Iran 
have nuclear weapons," Trump told Fox News. "I don't want to fight. But you do have situations like Iran, you can't 
let them have nuclear weapons - you just can't let that happen," he said. Prior to the interview Trump had appeared 
to escalate the growing threat of conflict when he used social media to respond to Iran's Revolutionary Guard 
saying it was not afraid of war. "If Iran wants to fight, that will be the official end of Iran. Never threaten the US 
again!" Trump wrote on Twitter, seemingly in response to comments Revolutionary Guard Corps commander 
Hossein Salami made earlier in the day.
----------
US energy company Exxon Mobil's evacuation of its foreign staff from a major Iraqi oil field is "unacceptable and 
unjustified," Iraqi Oil Minister Thamir Ghadhban said Sunday. On Saturday, the US-based firm evacuated 50 US 
employees from Iraq and flew them to Dubai in the United Arab Emirates amid escalating tensions between the US 
and Iran, according to sources in the Iraqi oil industry. Ghadhban said Sunday the evacuations were not due to 
security threats in Iraq, instead blaming "political reasons, attributed to political tensions in the region." The 50 
evacuees had worked at the West Qurna 1 oil field in Iraq's southern province of Basra.
----------
Another seat was added on Monday to Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative coalition as he 
inched closer to forming majority government two days after the federal election. The Australian Electoral 
Commission's latest figures showed Morrison's Liberal Party coalition with the Nationals was projected to win 75 
seats, just one short of a majority in the 151-member lower house of parliament.
----------
Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz called for fresh elections "as soon as possible" after a corruption scandal 
forced his deputy - the leader of the far-right Freedom Party (FPOe) - to step down. Kurz told a press conference in 
Vienna that his conservative People's Party could no longer work in a coalition with the FPOe. "After yesterday's 
video, I must honestly say that enough is enough," he said. Kurz said he had made his position known to Austrian 
President Alexander Van der Bellen, who later said a new election was necessary to regain the trust of the Austrian 
public. The announcement comes one day after two German media outlets showed footage of FPOe leader Heinz-
Christian Strache offering government contracts in return for financial backing from a woman posing as a potential 
party donor and niece of a Russian oligarch.

Subprime lender Provident Financial received the backing of one of its prominent shareholders as it fends off the 
advances of smaller peer Non-Standard Finance. Asset manager Schroders, which holds a 15% stake in Provident, 
reiterated its view that Non-Standard Finance's offer is not in the best interest of Provident shareholders. Last week, 
Non-Standard Finance said its offer for Provident Financial has become unconditional. "We remain of the view that 
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Warns Of "Zero Visibility" Beyond Few Months
it is in the best interests of those Provident Financial shareholders who are not also shareholders in Non-Standard 
Finance to reject the NSF offer and continue to hold premium listed PFG stock, confident in the protection for 
minority shareholders that this provides," said Kevin Murphy, fund manager at Schroders.

IT infrastructure and services provide Softcat said it has continued to perform well in its third quarter and has 
delivered strong year-on-year growth across its income and profit measures. Softcat said it is confident in delivering 
annual results "slightly" ahead of expectations.

COMPANIES - OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM
----------
Estate agent Foxtons Group, ahead of its annual general meeting, said its first quarter performance was in line with 
the board's expectations. For the quarter ended March 31, revenue was GBP23.8 million compared to GBP24.5 
million in the first quarter last year. The company said revenue in its sales business declined as conditions in the 
London property market remains "very challenging". Moreover, Foxtons said sales volumes continue to be at record 
low levels and ongoing Brexit uncertainty is hurting consumer confidence. Revenue in its lettings business was 
marginally ahead of the prior year, continuing its progress following the initiatives the company implemented in 
2018.
----------
Project management consultant WYG has agreed to GBP43.4 million all-cash takeover offer from Tetra Tech. The 
55 pence per share offer has acceptances representing 72.5% of WYG shares, it said. WYG said the combination 
with Tetra Tech will create a premier international consulting, engineering and project management firm.
----------
COMPANIES - INTERNATIONAL
----------
Alphabet's Google has reportedly blocked Chinese communications company Huawei from using apps on its 
phones. Huawei is one of a number of phone manufacturers who use the Google-developed Android operating 
systems on its phones and tablets. The Verge has reported that Google has cut off Huawei's licence – meaning it 
will no longer be able to use apps like Maps and Gmail and will not have access to security updates. Existing 
customers will be able to update their phones and apps, but will not be able to update to a newer version of the 
Android operating system if one becomes available. Android said it had taken steps to "comply with the recent US 
government actions". This could be a reference to US president Donald Trump's executive order apparently aimed 
at banning Huawei's equipment from US networks and said it was subjecting the Chinese company to strict export 
controls.

TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair Annual Profit Falls; Unveils Share Buyback
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair Annual Profit Falls; Unveils Share Buyback
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 10:21 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Top News
Length: 1093 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following is a summary of top news stories Monday.
----------
COMPANIES
----------
Ryanair Holdings reported a significant fall in profit in a year which saw many EU airlines struggle due to higher oil 
prices and lower fares in a competitive market, and it warned of "zero" visibility on its results beyond the next few 
months. More positively, Ryanair approved a EUR700 million share buyback which will commence later this week 
and run for the next 9 to 12 months. For the financial year ended March 31, the Irish airline reported pretax profit of 
EUR948.1 million, down 41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at 
Lauda, Ryanair's Austrian airline.Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in financial 2020 to 153 million 
passengers. However, assuming revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit, 
including Lauda. This will range from EUR750 million if RPP rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if RPP rises 4%. 
----------
Softcat said it expects its annual results to be "slightly ahead" of previous expectations, as trading in the quarter to 
the end of April was strong. The FTSE 250-listed IT infrastructure provider said it continued to preform well in the 
three months to April 30, delivering "strong year-on-year growth" across all income and profit measures. 
"Performance drivers remained broad-based, with different technology areas and customer segments all showing 
growth," Softcat said. The company added that progress towards the opening of a new office in Birmingham is "well 
advanced". It expects the opening to occur early in the next financial year.
----------
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair Annual Profit Falls; Unveils Share Buyback
Foxtons Group said revenue declined in the first quarter as Brexit and a weak market in London took a toll on sales. 
Furthermore Mark Berry, the real estate agent's chief financial officer, will step down from Foxtons' board on June 
24 in "mutual agreement" with the company. Richard Harris has been appointed as CFO with effect from the same 
date. Foxtons said that performance in the three months ended March 31, was in line with the board's expectations. 
Group revenue came in at GBP23.8 million, down from GBP24.5 million in the first quarter of 2018. Sales revenue 
amounted to GBP7.1 million, down from GBP8.2 million a year prior, while lettings revenue was GBP14.6 million, 
broadly flat on GBP14.3 million a year ago.
----------
MARKETS
----------
London shares were lower amid the trade standoff between the US and China, with travel stocks weighing on the 
FTSE 100 following disappointing annual results from Ryanair. Oil was up after OPEC indicated it may sustain 
previous production cuts. Wall Street was pointed to a lower open.

UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to begin discussions with senior ministers on her proposed new "bold offer" 
to members of Parliament in a final attempt to get her Brexit deal through Parliament. The weekly meeting of the 
Cabinet on Tuesday is expected to sign off on a package of measures to be included in the forthcoming Withdrawal 
Agreement Bill aimed at winning cross-party support. However there was widespread scepticism at Westminster 
that it will fare any better than her three previous failed attempts to get the Commons to pass the deal. Following 
the collapse last week of cross-party talks with Labour aimed at reaching a common approach, Jeremy Corbyn said 
he had not yet seen anything new that would persuade him to support it. It comes at the start of what looks likely to 
be another torrid week for the prime minister with the Conservatives braced for a hammering at the hands of Nigel 
Farage's Brexit Party in the European elections on Thursday.
----------
Alphabet Inc's Google has confirmed it has blocked Huawei from updating some parts of its Android software used 
on Huawei phones to comply with a US government order blacklisting the Chinese firm. The tech giant said it was 
"complying with the order and reviewing the implications", but assured Huawei users that their current phones 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair Annual Profit Falls; Unveils Share Buyback
would continue to work. Last week, US President Donald Trump signed an executive order effectively banning the 
Chinese firm from using US technology without government permission. "For users of our services, Google Play 
and the security protections from Google Play Protect will continue to function on existing Huawei devices," a 
Google spokesman said. The block is likely to prevent future updates to Android reaching Huawei devices. Key 
Google apps such as the Google Play Store, Gmail and Google Maps may also not appear on future Huawei 
devices. Instead, the Chinese firm would be reliant on the version of Android available through an open source 
licence, which is vastly more limited in its features.
----------
The average price tag on a home coming freshly onto the market jumped by over GBP2,800 in May – meaning 
house hunters in some areas now face record high amounts being demanded by sellers. Across Britain, the 
average asking price is GBP308,290 – GBP2,841 or 0.9% higher than in April, according to the figures from 
Rightmove. The website, whose records go back over a decade, said Wales, the Midlands and the North West of 
England are "bucking any Brexit blues" – with average asking prices in these areas having reached new all-time 
highs.

"be the official end of Iran" when the country's Revolutionary Guard said it was not afraid of war. "I will not let Iran 
have nuclear weapons," Trump told Fox News. "I don't want to fight. But you do have situations like Iran, you can't 
let them have nuclear weapons - you just can't let that happen," he said. Prior to the interview Trump had appeared 
to escalate the growing threat of conflict when he used social media to respond to Iran's Revolutionary Guard 
saying it was not afraid of war. "If Iran wants to fight, that will be the official end of Iran. Never threaten the US 
again!" Trump wrote on Twitter, seemingly in response to comments Revolutionary Guard Corps commander 
Hossein Salami made earlier in the day.

LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London were seen opening higher on Monday amid mixed trading in 
Asia, ahead of another busy week of company earnings reports and politically sensitive elections to the European 
Parliament.
In early company news, Ryanair Holdings annual profit slumped 40% on higher fuel costs, Softcat said trading 
remains in line with expectations, and Provident Financial received the backing of one of its major shareholders in 
its ongoing battle with Non-Standard Finance. WYG agreed to a GBP43.4 million takeover.
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index is to open up 11.68 points at 7,360.30. The blue-chip index closed down 
4.89 points, or 0.1%, at 7,348.62 on Friday.
Irish carrier Ryanair Holdings reported a significant fall in its annual profit due to increased fuel, airport and staff 
costs.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 
41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's 
Austrian airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December.

revenue.

from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.

Cabinet Office said in Monday's preliminary reading.

which was originally reported as 0.5%. On an annualized yearly basis, GDP was up 2.1% - again exceeding

UK Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to make a "bold offer" to members of Parliament in a final attempt to 
get her beleaguered Brexit deal through Parliament and onto the statue book before she leaves office.
Minister will begin discussions on Monday on a package of measures to be included in the forthcoming Withdrawal 
Agreement Bill aimed at securing cross-party support. The weekly meeting of the Cabinet on Tuesday will then 
consider plans for a series of "indicative votes" in the Commons to establish which proposals could command a 
majority in the House.
The move follows the final collapse on Friday of cross-party talks with Labour aimed at finding an agreed way 
forward which would allow Britain to leave the EU with a deal.
"As it becomes clearer that Prime Minister Theresa May's premiership is in its final death throes attention is shifting 
to a number of different outcomes, including but not confined to, who her successor is likely to be, the collapse of 
the government, a new election and the prospect of a possible minority Labour government," added Hewson.
The economic events calendar on Monday has eurozone current account numbers at 1000 BST.

LONDON MARKET MIDDAY: Airline Stocks Dip; Another Setback For Huawei
LONDON MARKET MIDDAY: Airline Stocks Dip; Another Setback For Huawei
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 10:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 1044 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Travel stocks were among the worst performers at the start of the week following 
disappointing results from Ryanair, as London stocks in general saw broad-based losses amid continuation of US-
China trade spat.
The FTSE 100 was down 54.06 points, or 0.7%, at 7,294.56 Monday midday. The mid-cap FTSE 250 was down 
139.54 points, or 0.7%, at 19,359.07. The AIM All-Share was down 0.1% at 958.20.
The Cboe UK 100 index was down 0.8% at 12,369.86. The Cboe UK 250 was down 0.7% at 17,393.69, though the 
Cboe UK Small Companies was flat at 11,848.70.
"News that the decision to implement auto tariffs would be delayed caused a recovery into the end of last week, but 
this morning we received a timely reminder that this could well get worse before it gets better," commented David 
Cheetham, chief market analyst at XTB.
Alphabet Inc's Google confirmed it has blocked Huawei from updating some parts of its Android software used on 
Huawei phones to comply with a US government order blacklisting the Chinese firm.
The tech giant said it was "complying with the order and reviewing the implications", but assured Huawei users that 
their current phones would continue to work.
Last week, US President Donald Trump signed an executive order effectively banning the Chinese firm from using 
US technology without government permission.
LONDON MARKET MIDDAY: Airline Stocks Dip; Another Setback For Huawei
Meanwhile, the UK Government has said it is yet to make a decision on whether to allow another part of Huawei's 
business, its telecoms equipment, to be a part of new 5G networks in the UK.
Remaining in the UK, the contest to succeed Prime Minister Theresa May is hotting up, with potential leadership 
candidates setting out their stalls.
Health Secretary Matt Hancock refused to rule out a bid for the job, saying he had a "strong view about the sort of 
leader we need". Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has already confirmed he will stand in the race to replace 
May, which is due to officially begin within weeks.
The prime minister will set out the timetable for her exit and the leadership contest to succeed her after a crunch 
vote on the legislation for her Brexit deal in early June.
The pound was quoted at USD1.2739 at midday, broadly unchanged from USD1.2737 late Friday.
In European equities, the CAC 40 in Paris and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt were down 1.2% and 1.3% respectively. 
In the US, Wall Street is on track for a downbeat start to the week. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 are both called 
down 0.1%, while the Nasdaq is pointed 0.5% lower. 
Oil was largely unchanged start of the week, quoted at USD72.62 Monday midday versus USD72.60 late Friday 
amid further deterioration in US-Iranian relations. 
The price of Brent had surpassed USD73 a barrel overnight before falling back in morning trade.
US President Donald Trump vowed Sunday to deny Tehran nuclear weapons just hours after threatening it would 
"be the official end of Iran" when the country's Revolutionary Guard said it was not afraid of war.
"If Iran wants to fight, that will be the official end of Iran. Never threaten the US again!" Trump wrote on Twitter, 
seemingly in response to comments Revolutionary Guard Corps commander Hossein Salami made earlier in the 
day.
Tensions have been escalating between the two countries since Tehran announced it would begin a partial 
withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal, from which Washington pulled out of last year.
"With Donald Trump threatening the Iran's aggression towards the US would see 'the end' of the Islamic Republic, 
there was plenty reasoning behind the weekend gap higher. However, we are also seeing cracks in the OPEC+ 
story, with the Russians talking about a potential easing of the output restrictions," said Joshua Mahony, senior 
market analyst at IG.
"Saudi threats that any relaxing of the current production levels could spark a glut of oil on the market have certainly 
raised concerns amongst crude traders, with prices falling in early trade today," he added.
As well as a volatile oil price hitting travel stocks - on fears of higher fuel prices - disappointing guidance from 
budget airline Ryanair.
Irish carrier Ryanair, down 2.5% at midday, reported a 41% fall in annual profit to EUR948.1 million despite revenue 
rising 6% to EUR7.69 billion.
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in financial 2020 to 153 million passengers. However, assuming 
revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit, including Lauda. This will range 
from EUR750 million if revenue per passenger rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if revenue per passenger rises 4%. 
LONDON MARKET MIDDAY: Airline Stocks Dip; Another Setback For Huawei
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through Summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," the company added.
Ryanair's results hit other airlines in a negative read-across, with FTSE 100 constituents TUI and easyJet down 
3.7% and 1.3% respectively. 
Beleaguered travel agent Thomas Cook was down 18%, furthering Friday's 40% slide after analysts at Citigroup cut 
the stock's price target to zero following a sharply wider interim loss. 
In the FTSE 250, Merlin Entertainments slipped 6.2% after HSBC cut the Legoland owner to Reduce from Buy. 
Also hurting from a rating downgrade was Metro Bank, lowered to Sell from Hold by Investec. 
This comes following a turbulent period for the challenger bank, as it last week raised more than initially anticipated 
after being hit by macroeconomic difficulties, such as regulatory changes and a low-interest rate environment, as 
well as "company-specific factors".
In January, the lender announced it had underestimated the risk on its commercial loans and needed to raise 
capital to compensate for the shortfall.
Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings, meanwhile, motored to the top of the mid-caps as Bernstein boosted the 
luxury car maker to Outperform from Market Perform. 
IT infrastructure firm Softcat rose 1.9% as the firm said its annual results are expected to be "slightly ahead" of prior 
expectations. The FTSE 250 constituent said it continued to preform well in the three months to April 30, delivering 
"strong year-on-year growth" across all income and profit measures.

LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks Higher As Earnings Season Continues
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks Higher As Earnings Season 
Continues
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 06:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 718 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are seen opening higher on Monday amid mixed trading in Asia, 
ahead of another busy week of company earnings reports and elections to the European Parliament in the UK and 
elsewhere.
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index is to open up 11.68 points at 7,360.30. The blue-chip index closed down 
4.89 points, or 0.1%, at 7,348.62 on Friday. 
"European markets look set to open slightly higher in the wake of this mixed Asia session, in a week of some 
important continent wide elections," said CMC Markets analyst Michael Hewson. 
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index is up 0.3%. In China, the Shanghai Composite is down 0.9%, while the Hang Seng 
index in Hong Kong is down 0.7%
Japan's gross domestic product climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.5% on quarter in the first quarter of 2019, the 
Cabinet Office said in Monday's preliminary reading.
That beat forecasts for a fall 0.1% and was up from the downwardly revised 0.4% gain in the three months prior, 
which was originally reported as 0.5%. On an annualized yearly basis, GDP was up 2.1% - again exceeding 
expectations for a fall of 0.2% following the downwardly revised 1.6% gain in the previous three months - originally 
1.9%.
In the US on Friday, Wall Street ended lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4%, S&P 500 down 
0.6% and Nasdaq Composite ending 1.0% lower.
The pound was quoted at USD1.2735 early Monday, flat against USD1.2737 at the London equities close Friday. 
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks Higher As Earnings Season Continues
UK Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to make a "bold offer" to members of Parliament in a final attempt to 
get her beleaguered Brexit deal through Parliament and onto the statue book before she leaves office.
Minister will begin discussions on Monday on a package of measures to be included in the forthcoming Withdrawal 
Agreement Bill aimed at securing cross-party support. The weekly meeting of the Cabinet on Tuesday will then 
consider plans for a series of "indicative votes" in the Commons to establish which proposals could command a 
majority in the House.
The move follows the final collapse on Friday of cross-party talks with Labour aimed at finding an agreed way 
forward which would allow Britain to leave the EU with a deal.
"As it becomes clearer that Prime Minister Theresa May's premiership is in its final death throes attention is shifting 
to a number of different outcomes, including but not confined to, who her successor is likely to be, the collapse of 
the government, a new election and the prospect of a possible minority Labour government," added Hewson. 
Ryanair Holdings early Monday reported a significant fall in its annual profit due to increased fuel, airport and staff 
costs.
For the financial year that ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 
41% from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's 
Austrian airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December.
Group revenue rose 6% to EUR7.69 billion from EUR7.15 billion, with an increase in both scheduled and ancillary 
revenue.
Fuel & oil costs rose 23% to EUR2.42 billion from EUR1.90 billion, staff costs increased 28% to EUR945.0 million 
from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.
The corporate calendar on Monday also has annual results from shipping services provider Braemar Shipping 
Services. There is also third-quarter results from IT infrastructure provider Softcat. 
On Tuesday this week, there are full-year results from car parts retailer Halfords Group and half-year results from 
sandwich maker Greencore Group.
On Wednesday, there are annual results from clothing and homewares retailer Marks & Spencer, postal operator 
Royal Mail and energy supplier SSE. On Thursday, water company United Utilities reports annual results. 
The economic events calendar on Monday has Germany producer prices at 0700 BST and eurozone current 
account numbers at 1000 BST. 
Also ahead this week, there are UK inflation readings and US Federal Reserve meeting minutes on Wednesday 
while the European Parliament elections take place on Thursday.
