LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Huawei Blow And Ryanair Woe Puts Pressure On FTSE
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Huawei Blow And Ryanair Woe Puts Pressure 
On FTSE
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 3:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 1253 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - London stocks started the new week on the back foot following another knock back for 
Chinese tech giant Huawei amid an ongoing US-Sino trade saga.
Travel stocks also played a role in denting the FTSE 100's performance on Monday after some ill-received 
guidance from budget airline Ryanair knocked peers in a negative read-across. 
However, London's blue-chip index managed to avoid the sharper loss of its European peers as the pound 
remained weak ahead of the likely return of UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit withdrawal deal in June. 
The FTSE 100 index closed down 37.74 points, or 0.5%, at 7,310.88. The FTSE 250 ended down 163.02 points, or 
0.8%, at 19,335.59, and the AIM All-Share closed down 1.68 points, or 0.2%, at 957.01.
The Cboe UK 100 ended down 0.6% at 12,386.37, the Cboe UK 250 closed down 0.8% at 17,375.66, and the Cboe 
Small Companies ended down 0.1% at 11,840.44.
In European equities on Monday, the CAC 40 in Paris ended down 1.5%, while the DAX 30 in Frankfurt ended 
down 1.6%.
"European stocks plummeted on Monday, as investors reacted to escalating US-Sino trade tensions. Google 
halting supplies to Chinese telecoms giant Huawei amid a White House ban has intensified the risk-off sentiment," 
said Fiona Cincotta, senior market analyst at City Index. 
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Huawei Blow And Ryanair Woe Puts Pressure On FTSE
Alphabet Inc's Google confirmed it has blocked Huawei from updating some parts of its Android software used on 
Huawei phones to comply with a US government order blacklisting the Chinese firm.
Last week, US President Donald Trump signed an executive order effectively banning the Chinese firm from using 
US technology without government permission. This came after the US increased tariffs to 25% on USD200 billion 
worth of Chinese products.
However, the dollar earner-heavy FTSE 100 posted less severe falls compared to European counterparts "thanks 
to cushioning from the pound", Cincotta noted. 
The pound was quoted at USD1.2731 at the London equities close Monday, soft compared to USD1.2737 at the 
close on Friday.
UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to begin discussions with senior ministers on her proposed new "bold offer" 
to members of Parliament in a final attempt to get her Brexit deal passed.
The weekly meeting of the Cabinet on Tuesday is expected to sign off on a package of measures to be included in 
the forthcoming Withdrawal Agreement Bill aimed at winning cross-party support.
However, there was widespread scepticism at Westminster that it will fare any better than her three previous failed 
attempts to get the Commons to pass the deal - all having failed with resounding margins.
Following the collapse last week of cross-party talks with Labour aimed at reaching a common approach, Jeremy 
Corbyn said he had not yet seen anything new that would persuade him to support it.
This comes at the start of what is likely to be another torrid week for the prime minister with the Conservatives 
braced for a thrashing at the hands of Nigel Farage's Brexit Party in the European elections on Thursday.
Meanwhile, Conservative members of Parliament have begun to throw their hats in the ring for May's job as she 
prepares to set out her own departure plan. 
Health Secretary Matt Hancock refused to rule out a bid for the job, saying he had a "strong view about the sort of 
leader we need". Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has already confirmed he will stand in the race to replace 
May, which is due to officially begin within weeks.
The prime minister will set out the timetable for her exit and the leadership contest to succeed her after her Brexit 
deal goes to the Commons for a fourth time in early June.
The euro stood at USD1.1169 at the European equities close Monday, against USD1.1160 at the same time on 
Friday.
Stocks in New York were trading in the red at the London equities close, with the DJIA down 0.3%, the S&P 500 
index down 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite down 1.2%. 
In London, travel firms ended the session among the worst performers after a disappointing outlook from Irish 
airline Ryanair, as the firm warned it has "zero" visibility on the second half. 
Ryanair closed down 4.6%.
The budget flier reported a 41% fall in annual profit to EUR948.1 million despite revenue rising 6% to EUR7.15 
billion.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Huawei Blow And Ryanair Woe Puts Pressure On FTSE
Looking ahead, the airline expects traffic to rise 8% in its recently-begun financial year to 153 million passengers. 
However, assuming revenue per passenger growth of 3%, Ryanair guided for broadly flat group profit. 
This will range from EUR750 million if revenue per passenger rises 2%, up to EUR950 million if revenue per 
passenger rises 4%. 
"While first half bookings are slightly ahead of last year, fares are lower and we expect this trend will continue 
through summer 2019. We have zero second half visibility," the company added.
Ryanair's results hit other travel stocks in a negative read-across, with FTSE 100 members TUI and easyJet 
shedding 6.2% and 3.5% respectively, while Wizz Air in the FTSE 250 declined 2.0%. 
Travel agent Thomas Cook came close to 2011's record low of 8.11 pence, finishing the session down 13% at 
10.25p as it extended last week's losses. 
In morning trade on Monday, the stock hit 8.33p per share. 
Last week, Thomas Cook posted an underlying loss before interest and tax loss of GBP245 million versus a loss of 
GBP170 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the firm said it now expects underlying Ebit in the second half to be 
behind the same period a year ago due to margin pressure.
Following the results, Citigroup cut the stock to Sell from Neutral and wiped its price target to 0p.
Back in the FTSE 100, Land Securities fell 1.6% after Liberum cut the property investor and developer to Hold from 
Buy.
A ratings downgrade saw Merlin Entertainments end as the biggest loser in the FTSE 250, sinking 6.7% after HSBC 
cut the Thorpe Park operator to Reduce from Buy. 
Elsewhere on the Main Market, Low & Bonar sank 24% on the impending departure of its chief executive and news 
that its performance in the first half of its financial year will be "materially behind" a year before.
Philip de Klerk will step down as CEO on July 1 and the company will promote Non-Executive Chair Daniel Dayan 
to executive chair on July 2. The company does not plan to seek a new CEO straight away, but will review the 
situation "later in the year".
The performance materials firm also said it has made a slower recovery than expected in its second quarter, which 
ends May 31. This was attributed to continued market weakness and "the slow recovery of customer confidence" 
within its Coated Technical Textiles unit, which creates modified fabrics for outdoor use.
In the UK corporate calendar on Tuesday, there are annual results from electronics product distributor 
Electrocomponents, car parts and bike retailer Halfords, emergency repairs firm Homeserve and food producer 
Cranswick.
There are third-quarter results from books and stationery retailer WH Smith and a trading statement from gold miner 
Fresnillo. 
In commodities, gold was quoted at USD1,276.80 an ounce at the London equities close Monday against 
USD1,275.10 at the close on Friday.
Brent oil, meanwhile, was quoted at USD72.56 a barrel at the London equities close Monday from USD72.60 late 
Friday.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Huawei Blow And Ryanair Woe Puts Pressure On FTSE
In the economic calendar on Tuesday, the Confederation of British Industry's Industrial Trends survey is at 1100 
BST, while in the US the Redbook index is at 1355 BST and eurozone consumer confidence at 1500 BST.

WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Results, Outlook Knock Travel Stocks
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Results, Outlook Knock Travel 
Stocks
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 09:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 675 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following stocks are the leading risers and fallers within the main London indices 
on Monday.
----------
FTSE 100 - LOSERS
----------
TUI, down 2.7%, easyJet, down 1.7%, International Consolidated Airlines Group, down 1.2%. The travel stocks 
were lower following disappointing annual results from Ryanair Holdings. The Irish carrier reported a significant fall 
in profit in a year which saw many EU airlines struggle due to higher oil prices and lower fares in a competitive 
market, and it warned of "zero" visibility on its results beyond the next few months. Ryanair shares were down 
3.8%. 
----------
FTSE 250 - WINNERS
----------
Aston Martin Lagonda, up 3.6%. Bernstein raised the luxury sports car maker to Outperform from Market Perform. 
Last week, Aston Martin report a pretax loss for the first quarter of 2019 of GBP17.3 million, after a GBP2.8 million 
profit the year prior. The gross margin was down to 42% from 44%. Aston Martin sold 1,057 units during the 
quarter, up 10% year-on-year, with revenue rising 6% to GBP196.0 million. It lowered its expectations for the full 
year as a result. The strock remains down 24% so far in 2019.
----------
FTSE 250 - LOSERS
----------
Merlin Entertainments, down 5.8%. HSBC downgraded the amusement park and attractions operator to Reduce 
from Buy. 
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Results, Outlook Knock Travel Stocks
----------
Metro Bank, down 2.8%. Investec cut the challenger bank to Sell from Hold after its GBP350 million share placing 
last week. 
----------
OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM - WINNERS
----------
Frontier Smart Technologies Group, up 71% at 25.25p. The audio and smart home software systems producer said 
it failed to reach an agreement with Science Group in respect of a takeover offer for Frontier. At the beginning of 
May, Frontier received a proposal from Science Group for a possible takeover offer at 30p per share. Frontier said it 
"remains focussed on its strategy" and reconfirmed expectations to report sales of approximately USD36.6 million. 
Furthermore, Frontier added that between May 9 and 17, Science Group acquired 3.7 million shares, or 9.0% of the 
company's capital. Science Group, a science and technology consultancy, separately noted that the average price 
paid for the shares was 12.50 pence for a total investment of GBP460,691. Science Group was up 1.3% at 
205.70p.
----------
Echo Energy, up 20%. The oil and gas company announced a switch in focus in Argentina as well as a new chief 
executive. Echo has agreed to a new relationship with Argentina partner Compania General de Combustibles, 
which will see the two focus on Echo's Tapi Aike licence. Echo will now hold 19% of the licence and pay 19% of 
costs, "significantly" lowering the company's obligations. CGC will release USD2.1 million of cash earmarked for the 
Fraccion C, Fraccion D, and Laguna Los Capones assets to go to Tapi Aike. On the management front, Echo 
announced the promotion of Martin Hull as chief executive with immediate effect. He replaces Fiona MacAulay, who 
stepped down in December.
----------
OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM - LOSERS
----------
Low & Bonar, down 28%. The performance materials maker announced the upcoming departure of its chief 
executive and said its performance in the first half of its financial year will be "materially behind" the year before. 
Philip de Klerk will step down as CEO on July 1 and the company will move Non-Executive Chair Daniel Dayan to 
executive chair on July 2. The company does not plan to seek a new CEO straight away, but will review the 
situation "later in the year". The company said its leadership change stemmed from a need to accelerate its 
transformation programme, which began in late 2018. The firm also said it has made a slower recovery than 
expected in its second quarter, which ends May 31. This was attributed to continued market weakness and "the 
slow recovery of customer confidence" within its Coated Technical Textiles unit, which creates modified fabrics for 
outdoor use.
----------

LONDON MARKET OPEN: Oil Stocks Lift FTSE 100; Ryanair Grounds Airlines
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Oil Stocks Lift FTSE 100; Ryanair Grounds 
Airlines
Alliance News
May 20, 2019 Monday 07:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 899 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London opened mixed on Monday, with oil majors among the best 
performers in the FTSE 100 on a firm oil price and rising tensions between the US and Iran, while airlines fell after 
Ryanair reported a drop in annual profit. 
The FTSE 100 was up 7.30 points, or 0.1%, at 7,355.92. The FTSE 250 was down 19.71 points, or 0.1% at 
19,478.90. The AIM All-Share was up 0.1% at 960.10.
The Cboe UK 100 index was up 0.1% at 12,475.79. The Cboe UK 250 was down 0.1% at 17,503.40, and the Cboe 
UK Small Companies was flat at 11,850.56.
In European equities, the CAC 40 in Paris was down 0.2% and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt was down 0.1%. 
In the FTSE 100, oil majors were the best performer, tracking spot oil prices higher, quoted at USD73.20 Monday, 
up from USD72.60 at the London equities close Friday.
Royal Dutch Shell 'A' and 'B' shares were both up 0.7% and BP was up 0.6%. Shell is London's biggest company 
by market capitalisation, while BP is third.
Oil prices were higher after Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih indicated there was consensus among OPEC and 
allied oil producers to continue limiting supplies.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Oil Stocks Lift FTSE 100; Ryanair Grounds Airlines
London Capital Group's Jasper Lawler commented: "Oil has already rallied around 40% since the start of the year, 
thanks mainly to OPEC limiting supply. Investors had been growing nervous that OPEC could look to remove the 
production limits at its next meeting in June, in light of tightening global supply and elevated prices. 
"Whilst the OPEC production cuts have offered significant support to oil prices, US sanctions on Iran and 
Venezuela have also played a role. Add into the equation rising Middle Eastern tensions, as Iran retaliates to US 
measures and oil looks well supported at these levels."
At the other end of the large cap index, airline stocks were the worst performers following disappointing annual 
results from Irish carrier Ryanair Holdings. 
Ryanair shares were down 6.4%. easyJet was down 2.5% and British Airways-parent International Consolidated 
Airlines Group was down 1.5%.
Ryanair reported a significant fall in annual profit due to increased fuel, airport and staff costs, and it said it has 
"zero" visibility on its likely results beyond the first half of the current year.
For the financial year ended March 31, the Irish budget airline reported pretax profit of EUR948.1 million, down 41% 
from EUR1.61 billion the year prior. This included a pretax loss of EUR182.7 million at Lauda, Ryanair's Austrian 
airline established by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda and acquired by Ryanair in December.
Fuel & oil costs rose 23% to EUR2.42 billion from EUR1.90 billion, staff costs increased 28% to EUR945.0 million 
from EUR738.5 million, and airport charges rose 9% to EUR1.02 billion from EUR938.6 million, hurting profit.
In the FTSE 250, Aston Martin Lagonda was the best performer, up 4.6% after Bernstein raised the luxury sports 
car maker to Outperform from Market Perform. 
At the other end of the midcap index, Merlin Entertainments was the worst performer, down 4.8% after HSBC 
downgraded the amusement park and attractions operator to Reduce from Buy. 
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.2%. In China, the Shanghai Composite closed down 0.9%, while the 
Hang Seng index in Hong Kong is down 0.7%
Japan's gross domestic product climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.5% on quarter in the first quarter of 2019, the 
Cabinet Office said in Monday's preliminary reading.
That beat forecasts for a fall 0.1% and was up from the downwardly revised 0.4% gain in the three months prior, 
which was originally reported as 0.5%. On an annualized yearly basis, GDP was up 2.1% - again exceeding 
expectations for a fall of 0.2% following the downwardly revised 1.6% gain in the previous three months - originally 
1.9%.
The pound was quoted at USD1.2732 Monday, flat against USD1.2737 at the London equities close Friday.
UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to begin discussions with senior ministers on her proposed new "bold offer" 
to members of Parliament in a final attempt to get her Brexit deal through Parliament.
The weekly meeting of the Cabinet on Tuesday is expected to sign off on a package of measures to be included in 
the forthcoming Withdrawal Agreement Bill aimed at winning cross-party support.
However, there was widespread scepticism at Westminster that it will fare any better than her three previous failed 
attempts to get the Commons to pass the deal.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Oil Stocks Lift FTSE 100; Ryanair Grounds Airlines
Following the collapse last week of cross-party talks with Labour aimed at reaching a common approach, opposition 
leader Jeremy Corbyn said he had not yet seen anything new that would persuade him to support it.
"Politics will continue to hog the lime-light in the UK in the coming week, although all indications now are that 
Theresa May will eschew the series of indicative Brexit votes in Parliament that was at one stage mooted for the 
first half of this week. With the next key Brexit event now likely to be the 'second reading' vote on May's Withdrawal 
Agreement Bill in the week commencing 3 June, all eyes this week will be on the European Parliament election on 
Thursday, which looks set to see May's Conservatives humiliated," said analysts at Daiwa Capital Markets. 
The economic events calendar on Monday has eurozone current account numbers at 1000 BST.

EXTRA: easyJet Shares Take Off Despite Widened Interim Loss
EXTRA: easyJet Shares Take Off Despite Widened Interim Loss
Alliance News
May 17, 2019 Friday 10:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Significant
Length: 795 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Shares in low-cost airline easyJet PLC rose on Friday as it kept annual expectations 
unchanged despite posting a sharp widening to its interim loss.
easyJet shares were trading up 3.6% on Friday, with the stock toppling the FTSE 100 index. 
The airline said it saw high-single-digit revenue growth in the first half of its current financial year but loss widened, 
in line with forecasts, due to an increase in fuel costs. 
"Budget airline easyJet becomes the latest travel stock to post a big loss as it reports first half results, but its shares 
are taking off regardless," AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould said.
He added: "This is reward for the tight control of costs which means despite lower revenue per seat, full year profit 
guidance is unchanged.
"These results were always likely to compare unfavourably with last year's which benefited from scheduling 
problems at main rival Ryanair and the collapse of Monarch Airlines. It is a tough time to be an airline in general 
with rising labour costs, excess capacity and spiralling fuel costs, not to mention the growing pressure on the whole 
concept of flying from environmental campaigners."
Mould concluded: "Against this stormy backdrop, easyJet perhaps has a clearer flight path than some of its peer 
group."
In the six months to March 31, easyJet's pretax loss came in at GBP272 million compared to GBP68 million 
reported for the same period a year earlier.
Fuel cost per seat jumped 14% in the period to GBP13.02 from GBP11.42 the year before, driven by a rise in oil 
prices.
EXTRA: easyJet Shares Take Off Despite Widened Interim Loss
easyJet's total fuel costs increased 31% in the first half to GBP602 million from GBP461 million the year prior. As a 
result, the airline's headline cost per seat increased 3.9% to GBP56.66 from GBP54.53.
Nevertheless, the company's revenue increased 7.3% to GBP2.34 billion from GBP2.18 billion the year before. 
Total revenue per seat, however, was down by 6.3% to GBP50.71 from GBP54.10. 
"easyJet has performed in line with expectations in the first half. I am pleased that despite tougher trading 
conditions, we flew more than 41 million customers, performed well operationally, with 54% fewer cancellations in 
the period and customer satisfaction with our crew is at an all-time high," said Chief Executive Johan Lundgren.  
The total revenue increase was attributed to a growth in capacity, which rose 14% year-on-year to 46.2 million, and 
a foreign exchange benefits. 
Load factor, a key measure for airlines, came in at 90.1%, down from 91.1% the year before. 
However, the company noted that its revenue was negatively impacted by the move of the Easter holiday and 
change to the IFRS 15 accounting standard.
In addition, easyJet said the issues at Gatwick Airport over Christmas caused by an errant drone cost it GBP5 
million in revenue. 
The airline said it had received one-off benefits in the corresponding period a year ago due to the bankruptcy of 
Monarch and Ryanair Holdings PLC "cancelling a large proportion of its winter 2017/8 schedule in the UK". 
Nonetheless, easyJet kept its full-year headline pretax profit expectations unchanged and in line with markets 
expectations. 
Forward bookings for the third quarter are expected to be three percentage points behind last year at 72% and flat 
year-on-year at 34% for the fourth quarter. easyJet's capacity growth in the second half is forecast at about 7%.
Revenue per seat, at constant currency, is expected to be "slightly down" in financial 2019, hurt by the "ongoing 
negative impact" of Brexit as well as a "wider macroeconomic slowdown" in Europe.  
The airline said it was prepared for the UK to leave the EU on March 29, and has 135 aircraft registered in Australia 
and is flying that fleet independently.
Full year headline cost per seat, excluding fuel at constant currency, is also expected to be down.
Meanwhile, reflecting the increase in revenue, and in line with its dividend policy, the airline hiked its interim payout 
43% to 58.6 pence from 40.9p the year before.
"Cost control remains a major priority for easyJet. Our focus is on efficiency and on innovation through data and we 
are on track to deliver more than GPB100 million in cost savings during 2019," said Lundgren. 
easyJet said it most of its savings in the first half came from the reduction in disruption events, which totalled 3,242 
compared to 4,815 a year prior. 
Lundgren added: "We have invested in the operation by doubling our standby aircraft and changed our schedules 
so that even though the external operating environment over the summer is not set to improve, we plan to alleviate 
the impact on our customers."  
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com and Paul McGowan; paulmcgowan@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved. 
Load-Date: May 17, 2019
EXTRA: easyJet Shares Take Off Despite Widened Interim Loss
End of Document
TOP NEWS: easyJet Interim Loss Widens Sharply On Increased Fuel Costs
TOP NEWS: easyJet Interim Loss Widens Sharply On Increased Fuel Costs
Alliance News
May 17, 2019 Friday 07:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Significant
Length: 628 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Low-cost airline easyJet PLC said on Friday it saw high-single-digit revenue growth in 
the first half of its current financial year but loss widened, in line with forecasts, due to an increase in fuel costs. 
In the six months to March 31, easyJet's pretax loss widened significantly to GBP272 million compared to a GBP68 
million loss reported for the same period a year earlier.
Fuel cost per seat jumped 14% in the period to GBP13.02 from GBP11.42 the year before, driven by a rise in oil 
prices.
easyJet's total fuel costs increased 31% in the first half to GBP602 million from GBP461 million the year prior. As a 
result, the airline's headline cost per seat increased 3.9% to GBP56.66 from GBP54.53.
Nevertheless, the company's revenue increased 7.3% to GBP2.34 billion from GBP2.18 billion the year before. 
Total revenue per seat, however, was down by 6.3% to GBP50.71 from GBP54.10. 
"easyJet has performed in line with expectations in the first half. I am pleased that despite tougher trading 
conditions, we flew more than 41 million customers, performed well operationally, with 54% fewer cancellations in 
the period and customer satisfaction with our crew is at an all-time high," said Chief Executive Johan Lundgren.  
The total revenue increase was attributed to a growth in capacity, which rose 14% year-on-year to 46.2 million, and 
a foreign exchange benefits. 
Load factor, a key measure for airlines, came in at 90.1%, down 1 percentage point from 91.1%. 
However, the company noted that its revenue was negatively impacted by the move of the Easter holiday and 
change to the IFRS 15 accounting standard.
TOP NEWS: easyJet Interim Loss Widens Sharply On Increased Fuel Costs
In addition, easyJet said the issues at Gatwick Airport over Christmas caused by an errant drone cost it GBP5 
million in revenue. 
The airline said it had received one-off benefits in the corresponding period a year ago due to the bankruptcy of 
Monarch and Ryanair Holdings PLC "cancelling a large proportion of its winter 2017/8 schedule in the UK".
Reflecting the increase in revenue, and in line with its dividend policy, the airline hiked its interim payout 43% to 
58.6 pence from 40.9p the year before.
"Cost control remains a major priority for easyJet. Our focus is on efficiency and on innovation through data and we 
are on track to deliver more than GPB100 million in cost savings during 2019," said Lundgren. 
easyJet said it most of its savings in the first half came from the reduction in disruption events, which totalled 3,242 
compared to 4,815 a year prior. 
Lundgren added: "We have invested in the operation by doubling our standby aircraft and changed our schedules 
so that even though the external operating environment over the summer is not set to improve, we plan to alleviate 
the impact on our customers."  
Looking ahead, the airline said its headline pretax profit expectations for financial 2019 remain unchanged and in 
line with market expectations. easyJet recorded a headline loss before tax of GBP275 million in the first half.
Forward bookings for the third quarter are expected to be 3 percentage points behind last year at 72% and flat year-
on-year at 34% for the fourth quarter. easyJet's capacity growth in the second half is forecast at about 7%.
Revenue per seat, at constant currency, is expected to be "slightly down" in financial 2019, hurt by the "ongoing 
negative impact" of Brexit as well as a "wider macroeconomic slowdown" in Europe.  
The airline said it was prepared for the UK to leave the EU on March 29, and has 135 aircraft registered in Australia 
and is flying that fleet independently.
Full year headline cost per seat, excluding fuel at constant currency, is also expected to be down.
By Paul McGowan; paulmcgowan@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved. 
Load-Date: May 17, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Recognizes Strikes As Reason For German Passenger Compensation
Ryanair Recognizes Strikes As Reason For German Passenger 
Compensation
Alliance News
May 14, 2019 Tuesday 05:42 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: Company Negative
Length: 255 words
Body
HAMBURG (Alliance News) - Dublin-based budget carrier Ryanair Holdings PLC has paid damages to individual 
passengers whose flights did not reach their destinations on time due to strikes, a Hamburg court said Monday.
In at least five legal proceedings, Ryanair recognized the demands of the plaintiff, a Hamburg court spokesman 
said.
Ryanair declined to comment on the proceedings.
Ryanair has previously refused to compensate passengers whose flights were cancelled due to strikes by Ryanair 
staff.
Under EU legislation for flight cancellations, an airline should pay EUR250 to each passenger, unless they are 
informed at least two weeks in advance or are offered alternative flights arriving at their destination the same day.
An airline can withhold compensation if it can show that the cancellation is "caused by extraordinary circumstances 
which could not have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken," according to the rules.
Last year, Ryanair argued that no compensation is payable "when the union is acting unreasonably and totally 
beyond the airline's control."
Air travel legal service provider Flightright, which has submitted lawsuits on behalf of hundreds of clients, disagrees, 
saying the company has provoked strikes with years of low wages and could have avoided an escalation of the 
labour action.
Flightright legal expert Oskar de Felice said the airline's behaviour was tactical, saying Ryanair wants to prevent the 
Hamburg court from pushing the issue on to the European Court of Justice.
Ryanair Recognizes Strikes As Reason For German Passenger Compensation
Copyright dpa
Load-Date: May 14, 2019
End of Document

Lufthansa Reveals Interest In Thomas Cook's Condor Holiday Airline
Lufthansa Reveals Interest In Thomas Cook's Condor Holiday Airline
Alliance News
May 7, 2019 Tuesday 10:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 175 words
Body
COLOGNE (Alliance News) - Deutsche Lufthansa AG Chief Executive Officer Carsten Spohr on Tuesday said the 
company has expressed its interest in the acquisition of the Condor holiday airline from the UK's Thomas Cook 
Group PLC. 
Speaking at the German air carrier's general meeting, Spohr said Lufthansa has officially conveyed a non-binding 
offer to Thomas Cook. 
Thomas Cook, with air operations in the UK, Scandinavia, Germany and Spain, has been troubled with financial 
concerns. Last week, the UK company said it has maintained a "healthy level of liquidity headroom" over the slower 
winter months and has kept its liquidity buffer on target.
The first deadline for the expressions of interest in Condor is on Tuesday. Wizz Air Holidings PLC, Ryanair Holdings 
PLC, easyJet PLC, and British Airways parent International Consolidated Airlines Group SA all reportedly have 
done so.
Spohr said Lufthansa is of the view that the acquisition of the long-haul route to tourist destinations from Frankfurt 
and Munich could be attractive.
Copyright RTT News/dpa-AFX
Load-Date: May 7, 2019
End of Document
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After 
M&A Woe
Alliance News
May 3, 2019 Friday 09:40 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 810 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Earnings were in focus over the past week in the consumer services sector, with J 
Sainsbury posting some good figures following its failed merger with Asda the week prior and Whitbread issuing its 
first annual results since selling its Costa Coffee chain to Coca-Cola.
Grocer Sainsbury's on Wednesday reported a 42% drop in pretax profit for the 52 weeks to March 9, not helped by 
almost GBP400 million of extra charges related to the aborted Asda merger, pension costs, and an overhaul of its 
banking platform. 
Revenue was up, though, by 1.9%, and underlying pretax profit beat expectations. Sainsbury's returned 11 pence 
to shareholders, up 7.8% year-on-year and ahead of consensus. 
The announcement came a day after Kantar said the UK's grocery sector picked up some pace in the 12 weeks to 
April 21, boosted by Easter spending, with Sainsbury's reclaiming second place from Asda in terms of market 
share. 
Turning to non-food retail, clothing and homewares chain Next on Wednesday beat its own sales expectations 
thanks to warmer weather at the end of April.
Sales in the thirteen weeks April 27 climbed 4.5%, ahead of expectations of a 3.2% rise, though Next did warn not 
to expect similar performance in the rest of the year. 
Fashion and homeware retailer N Brown on Thursday sunk to an annual loss after a profit, due to almost GBP150 
million of exceptional charges, treble a year prior. 
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
Revenue was broadly flat, with the Jacamo-owner saying performance was "solid" in the 52 weeks to March 2. 
However, it cut its annual dividend 50%, to 7.1p. 
Looking at the wider UK retail sphere, on Friday research firm BDO said good weather, the school holidays, and a 
late Easter failed to soothe the UK's suffering high streets.
High street retail sales fell 0.4% in April, BDO said, the third month of decline in 2019 already, while there has been 
next to no growth over the past 15 months. 
On Wednesday, shop price inflation was shown to have fallen to 0.4% in April from 0.9% in March by the BRC-
Nielsen Shop Price Index. The slowdown was caused by a more than doubling of the number of discounted 
products as retailers try to boost sales. 
There was also an initial public offering announced in the retail sector, with luxury retailer Watches of Switzerland 
announcing a plan to float in London.
The firm, which sells top watch brands such as Rolex, Tag Heuer, Omega, and Patek Philippe, did not provide 
many details, but did say it would offer both new shares and allow existing shareholders - primarily investment 
funds managed by an affiliate of Apollo Global Management - to sell theirs. 
On Thursday, budget airline Ryanair reported a 10% rise in April passenger numbers, including Austrian airline 
Lauda, reaching 13.0 million. 
On the same day, central and eastern Europe-focused peer Wizz Air posted 19% traffic growth, with passenger 
numbers reaching 3.3 million. 
Outside of the UK, German airline Lufthansa on Tuesday posted a significantly widened first quarter net loss, 
reaching EUR342 million from just EUR39 million a year prior. 
Lufthansa blamed the wider loss on a sharp rise in fuel costs and a deterioration in unit revenue in Europe. Overall 
revenue rose 3% to EUR7.89 billion. 
A week-long strike by SAS pilots ended on Thursday, though not before the Scandinavian airline had to cancel 
4,000 flights. 
The labour action was over concerns about scheduling, job security, and salaries, and affected around 380,000 
passengers. 
Moving into hospitality, Intercontinental Hotels Group on Friday reported subdued revenue per available room 
growth, rising 0.3% in the first quarter.
In the Americas, the figure rose 0.8%, with performance strong in the US, Mexico, and Colombia. 
Premier Inn-owner Whitbread on Tuesday posted a steep drop, 39%, in pretax profit for its year ended February 28, 
though it did rise 1.2% underlying. 
Whitbread booked GBP178 million in extra costs, much of which were due to its sale of Costa Coffee to Coca-Cola. 
Whitbread cut its annual dividend to 99.65p from 101.15p a year prior, and it also warned on weak revenue per 
room in the UK going forward. 
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
Moving to restaurants, brewer and pub owner Greene King on Tuesday guided for a rise in profit in its recently 
ended year, following solid sales growth.
Greene King said sales rose 2.9% ahead of the UK pub market for its year ended April 29, with trading over Easter 
strong. Profit before tax and exceptional items for the year to be in the range of GBP244 million and GBP247 
million, slightly ahead year-on-year.
On the same day, fast-food firm McDonald's said it had a strong start to 2019, despite a slight decline in net income 
and revenue.
Revenue fell 3.6% in the first quarter of 2019 due to refranchising, while net income dipped 3.4%. 
By George Collard; georgecollard@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: May 3, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair Reports 5% Traffic Growth While Wizz Air Sees 19% Rise
Ryanair Reports 5% Traffic Growth While Wizz Air Sees 19% Rise
Alliance News
May 2, 2019 Thursday 09:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UNKNOWN
Length: 255 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings PLC on Thursday reported 5% growth in 
comparable traffic for April, while smaller peer Wizz Air Holdings PLC achieved a much sharper rise.
Ryanair said group April passenger numbers rose to 13.0 million, excluding recent Austrian acquisition Lauda, from 
12.3 million a year ago. Including Lauda, total passenger numbers rose by 10% to 13.5 million.
On a rolling annual basis Ryanair's traffic was also up 9% to 142.3 million. The airline's load factor at group level 
stood at 96% both in April and over the 12-month rolling period. Lauda's was 92% in April.
Ryanair operated over 75,000 scheduled flights in April.
Meanwhile, central and eastern Europe-focused airline Wizz Air reported 19% traffic growth in April and said it 
continued to grow its network and improve customer offering.
For the month of April, Wizz Air passenger numbers increased to 3.3 million from 2.7 million. On a rolling 12 month 
basis, the airline recorded 17% growth in passenger numbers to 35.1 million.
The company increased its capacity - the number of available seats - by 18% in the month to 3.6 million and by 
15% in the past 12 month to 37.8 million.
Load factor in April rose to 91.9% from 90.9% a year ago. It was up 1.4 percentage point to 92.8% in the rolling 12 
months.
Shares in Ryanair were trading 1.4% lower at EUR12.03 per share. Wizz Air shares were up 1.6% at 3,489.00 
pence each.
By Tapan Panchal; tapanpanchal@alliancenews.com

WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Oil Stocks And Airlines Bookend FTSE 100
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Oil Stocks And Airlines Bookend FTSE 100
Alliance News
April 23, 2019 Tuesday 09:35 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 650 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following stocks are the leading risers and fallers within the main London indices 
on Tuesday.
----------
FTSE 100 - WINNERS
----------
Royal Dutch Shell 'A', up 2.5%, Shell 'B', up 2.2%, BP, up 2.2%. The oil majors were tracking spot oil prices higher, 
quoted at USD74.53 a barrel Tuesday, up from USD71.70 at the London equities close Thursday. Oil prices were 
higher after the US on Monday said it will not extend waivers to eight countries that have been allowed to buy oil 
from Iran despite US sanctions that went into effect in November. The move is "intended to bring Iran's oil exports 
to zero, denying the regime its principal source of revenue," according to the White House. In the FTSE 250, oil 
stocks Cairn Energy, Premier Oil and Tullow Oil were up 6.5%, 6.4% and 6.3% respectively. 
----------
Centrica, up 1.4%. The 'Big Six' energy provider plans to expand its software business, to cash in on increased 
demand for more flexible grid systems, the Financial Times reported on Monday. According to Jorge Pikunic, 
Centrica's managing director of Distributed Energy & Power, Centrica is looking to expand the segment's operations 
over the next three years by "almost fivefold". The group will look to grow the business into a software supplier to 
other companies, amid plans to increase the amount of renewable energy that currently makes up the UK's 
electricity supply.
----------
FTSE 100 - LOSERS
----------
easyJet, down 3.9%, International Consolidated Airlines Group, down 2.8%. The airline stocks were lower following 
the rise in the oil price. Higher oil prices result in increased fuel costs for airline operators. In the FTSE 250, Wizz 
Air was down 2.7%, while Irish carrier Ryanair Holdings was off 3.3%. "Airline stocks are also under pressure as 
news unfolds that French pilots may walk out in protest in May over a change in legislation. The strike has the 
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Oil Stocks And Airlines Bookend FTSE 100
potential to disrupt Air France and easyJet flights to and from France in May and comes at a time when airlines are 
beginning to feel the pinch of higher oil prices," said City Index analyst Fiona Cincotta. 
----------
FTSE 250 - WINNERS
----------
Travis Perkins, up 3.0%. Bank of America Merrill Lynch raised the builders' merchant to Buy from Neutral. 
----------
OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM - WINNERS
----------
Tekcapital, up 65%. The intellectual property investor said its portfolio company has launched a low-sodium salt 
under the name MicroSalt. The portfolio company, Salarius, develops and manufactures MicroSalt - salt crystals 
that are around 100 times smaller than table salt. These smaller grains produce a more powerful flavour, which 
means less sodium is consumed overall. In addition to the MicroSalt launch, Salarius has "secured its first customer 
to incorporate MicroSalt in their snack food business". The customer, whose name was not disclosed, is a US 
snack food maker, and the MicroSalt will be dispatched to it in May. Tekcapital owns a 97.5% stake in Salarius.
----------
Thomas Cook Group, up 17%. The travel agent's shares were higher after Sky News reported on Saturday that the 
company is in talks over a possible takeover. Sky said it learned that Thomas Cook has "brought in advisers from 
AlixPartners to work on its balance sheet and cost reduction plans, while its syndicate of more than a dozen lenders 
has hired FTI Consulting to advise on their financial exposure to Thomas Cook". Fosun, a Chinese company and 
Thomas Cook's largest shareholder, is reported to be "among those which have lodged a preliminary interest" in 
buying Thomas Cook's tour operating business. According to Sky: "Analysts also cited EQT and KKR, the two 
private equity firms which own Kuoni Group and Travelopia respectively, as logical bidders for the London-listed 
travel company".
----------

EU Court Dismisses Lufthansa Action On Subsidy For German Airport
EU Court Dismisses Lufthansa Action On Subsidy For German Airport
Alliance News
April 12, 2019 Friday 4:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 233 words
Body
LUXEMBOURG (Alliance News) - An EU court on Friday dismissed a legal action by German airline Deutsche 
Lufthansa AG that contested subsidies to Frankfurt-Hahn Airport and contracts it entered into with Dublin-based 
budget carrier Ryanair Holdings PLC.
Lufthansa, which does not use the airport, had failed to show that its business had been negatively affected enough 
to justify its complaint, the EU's General Court ruled.
At issue are subsidies worth millions of euros paid out in previous years. Lufthansa - Europe's largest airline if all its 
subsidiaries are included - alleged unfair competition.
It challenged a 2014 decision by the European Commission to approve the subsidies, on the basis that they were 
not in breach of EU competition rules.
Hahn lies some 120 kilometres from Frankfurt, where Lufthansa has its main hub.
The 2014 decision allowed payments to Hahn airport by Fraport, which operated both Hahn and Frankfurt Airport at 
the time, as well as two German states.
Of the three, only one of the German states - Hesse - still holds a minority share in Hahn. In 2017, China's HNA 
took over 82.5% of the airport.
The commission decided in 2014 that the support for Hahn airport was either not state subsidies or was compliant 
with EU subsidy rules.
Lufthansa said it would consider whether to challenge the decision before the European Court of Justice, the bloc's 
top tribunal.
Copyright dpa
EU Court Dismisses Lufthansa Action On Subsidy For German Airport

End of Document
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: easyJet Posts Warning, Wizz Air Soars
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: easyJet Posts Warning, Wizz Air 
Soars
Alliance News
April 5, 2019 Friday 11:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1103 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Airlines were in the spotlight this week after easyJet guided for a "significantly" widened 
interim loss and Wizz Air said its annual profit will land at the upper end of guidance. 
easyJet started off the week on Monday saying that macroeconomic and Brexit uncertainty would lead to a softer 
second half and a significantly widened interim loss.
For the six months to March-end, easyJet expects to report a headline pretax loss of around GBP275 million due to 
higher costs, fuel and foreign exchange charges. This compares to a headline loss of GBP18 million a year ago.
First-half revenue however is expected to rise 7.3% to GBP2.34 billion.
Looking ahead, the budget airline warned that the second half outlook is now even "more cautious" due to 
macroeconomic uncertainty leading to softness in both the UK and Europe.
Brexit uncertainty did not seem to affect smaller peer Wizz Air however, which on Tuesday reported further traffic 
growth in March and said annual profit would come in towards the top of its guidance.
The central and eastern Europe-focused airline said net profit for the year ended March 31 is expected to come in 
towards the upper half of the EUR270 million and EUR300 million guidance range. A year ago, Wizz Air's net profit 
amounted to EUR275 million.
This was after fourth quarter trading in line with expectations and "robust" demand across the company's key 
geographical territories, Wizz Air explained. 
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: easyJet Posts Warning, Wizz Air Soars
In March, Wizz Air passenger numbers rose 9.9% to 2.7 million. On a rolling 12 months basis, passenger numbers 
increased 17% to 34.6 million.
Meanwhile, another airline heavyweight, Ryanair Holdings, said March passenger numbers rose 9.0% to 10.9 
million. On a rolling annual basis, Ryanair's traffic was also up 9.0% to 142.1 million. 
Elsewhere, trouble continued across the retail sector with data released Friday suggesting that Mother's Day and 
warm spring weather failed to provide respite for the struggling UK high street in March.
A mere 4.8% rise in sales failed to counterbalance last March's dire 10% fall, the BDO's High Street Sales Tracker 
showed.
The latest figures closed a "disastrous" first quarter for the high street, BDO said.
Meanwhile, UK shop prices continued to rise in March, the British Retail Consortium-Nielsen Shop Price Index 
showed on Wednesday, with annual shop price inflation accelerating to 0.9% from 0.7% in February, marking the 
highest inflation rate since 2013.
Some retailers have continued to take advantage of the tough trading climate by hunting for cut-price deals.
FTSE 250 retailer JD Sports Fashion on Thursday bought Oasis singer Liam Gallagher's clothing brand Pretty 
Green out of administration for an undisclosed sum. 
JD Sports will keep the flagship store in Manchester open, but will shut down 11 other stores and 33 concessions, 
putting 97 jobs at risk.
Additionally, last month JD agreed to acquire shoe retailer Footasylum for GBP90.1 million.
Also looking to snap up businesses, Sports Direct International offered to acquire home shopping retailer Findel for 
GBP139.2 million. 
Findel however urged its shareholders to reject Sports Direct proposed takeover as it believes the offer 
"undervalues" the business.
On Monday, Findel received a letter from its second largest shareholder, Schroders Investment Management, 
supporting the company in its rejection of the offer.
Sports Direct's pursuit of taking over struggling department store chain operator Debenhams also continued with 
Sports Direct saying Monday that it has been contacted by a number of Debenhams' shareholders expressing 
support for the sports retailer's board requisition action. 
Sports Direct said Debenhams shareholders expressed concern regarding the protection of their own interests amid 
a refinancing of Debenhams and stated their support for the appointment of Sports Direct's boss Mike Ashley to 
Debenhams board as chief executive.
In March, Sports Direct called for a general meeting of Debenhams to propose Ashley's appointment to the board to 
carry out an executive role. Furthermore, Sports Direct is looking to oust all Debenhams directors bar one.
In a separate attempt to take control of Debenhams, Sports Direct has made a GBP61.4 million bid for the 
department store chain.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: easyJet Posts Warning, Wizz Air Soars
Women fashion retailer Bonmarche on Tuesday also found itself as the object of a takeover offer by Spectre 
Holdings Ltd, owned by Edinburgh Woollen Mill billionaire owner Philip Day.
The offer is priced at 11.445 pence per share and values the company at GBP5.7 million, a 34% discount to 
Bonmarche's GBP8.7 million market value Monday's close. 
Meanwhile, on Tuesday Superdry's co-founder and former chief executive Julian Dunkerton narrowly won a 
shareholder vote marking his return to the company's board. 
Superdry's shareholders voted in favour of two special resolutions proposed by the retailer's co-founders, which 
resulted in Dunkerton's reappointment and the appointment of Boohoo group's Peter Williams as director.
As a result of the votes, Superdry's Chair Peter Bamford, Chief Executive Euan Sutherland and Chief Financial 
Officer Ed Barker have stepped down with immediate effect, while Non-Executive Directors Dennis Millard, Minnow 
Powell, Sarah Wood and John Smith will leave their roles on July 1.
Finally, the Food retail sector saw Asda kicking out J Sainsbury taking the spot of the second biggest UK 
supermarket by market share, according to figures released by Kantar on Tuesday. 
Asda, in the 12 weeks to March 24, saw sales up by a miniscule 0.1% but reached market share of 15.4%. Over the 
same period, Sainsbury's sales dropped 1.8%, with market share down to 15.3%. 
Wm Morrison Supermarkets was the only other grocer seeing a decline in sales, dipping 0.1%, with its market share 
at 10.3%. Tesco saw sales up 0.5%, but its market share shed 0.2 percentage point to 27.4%. 
Overall, UK supermarkets saw sales up 1.4% year-on-year, the slowest rate in a year due to the later timing of 
Easter and Mother's Day.
A strong performance from its Food division helped Co-operative Group increasing annual pretax profit by 27% to 
GBP93 million. Revenue rose 14% to GBP10.2 billion the company said Friday. 
On Wednesday next week, UK biggest supermarket Tesco is out with its annual results. The grocer is expected to 
show a 22% surge in pretax profit to GBP1.6 billion.
On the same day, another retail heavyweight ASOS will publish its interim results with analysts forecasting a drop in 
profit to GBP3.5 million from GBP27.3 million a year ago. 
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com

TOP NEWS: Ryanair Traffic Grows, Wizz Air Profit To Top Guidance
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Traffic Grows, Wizz Air Profit To Top Guidance
Alliance News
April 2, 2019 Tuesday 06:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 390 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings PLC on Tuesday said its traffic grew in March, 
while smaller peer Wizz Air Holdings PLC experienced an even sharper rise.
Ryanair said March passenger numbers rose 9.0% to 10.9 million. On a rolling annual basis Ryanair's traffic was 
also up 9.0% to 142.1 million. 
The airline's load factor stood at 96% both in March and over the 12-month rolling period. 
Furthermore, Ryanair said its pilots based in Portugal voted in favour of a collective labour agreement governing 
pay and conditions for the next four years.
The agreement was negotiated between the airline and the Portuguese pilot union, SPAC, and covers all of 
Ryanair's directly employed pilots in Portugal.
Meanwhile, central and eastern Europe-focused airline Wizz Air Holdings PLC reported further traffic growth in 
March, as it said it expects its annual profit to come in towards the top of its guidance.
For the month of March, Wizz Air reported a 9.9% rise in passenger numbers to 2.7 million, while the increase was 
even greater, up 17% to 34.6 million, on a rolling 12 months basis. 
The company increased its capacity - the number of available seats - by 6.9% in March to 2.9 million and by 15% in 
the past 12 month to 37.3 million.
Load factor in March rose 2.6 percentage points to 94.1%. It was up 1.4 percentage point to 92.8% over the past 
year.
Wizz Air said it expects its annual net profit for the year ended March to come in towards the upper half of its 
guidance range of between EUR270 million and EUR300 million. A year ago, Wizz Air's net profit amounted to 
EUR275 million.
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Traffic Grows, Wizz Air Profit To Top Guidance
This was after fourth quarter trading in line with expectations and "robust" demand across the company's key 
geographical territories, Wizz Air explained. 
Wizz Air said it experienced an "excellent operational performance" in March with only one cancelled flight 
compared to 68 in March 2018. During the month, the airline expanded adding 15 new routes to  and from Poland, 
Romania, UK, Ukraine, Serbia and Moldova. 
Looking ahead, Wizz Air said it started the new year well, forecasting a 4.0% increase in revenue per available seat 
per kilometre in the first quarter. 
Wizz Air will report its annual results on May 31.

LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Edinburgh Woolen Mills' Day Bids For Bonmarche
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Edinburgh Woolen Mills' Day Bids For 
Bonmarche
Alliance News
April 2, 2019 Tuesday 06:46 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1100 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are seen opening higher on Tuesday following a strong close in 
the US overnight and gains in Asian equity markets, as investors reacted positively to US and Chinese 
manufacturing data released on Monday.
In company news, the spat between Provident Financial and Non-Standard Finance took another twist, BHP is 
lowering its iron ore guidance, Ryanair and Wizz Air issued upbeat trading statements, and womenswear retailer 
Bonmarche received a discounted takeover offer.
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index is to open up 15.02 points at 7,332.40. The blue-chip index closed up 38.19 
points, or 0.5%, at 7,317.38 on Monday.
Provident Financial said Chief Financial Officer Simon Thomas is to take up to three months leave starting on 
Friday to have a heart operation. Thomas is expected to return to work full time no later than June. The subprime 
lender said Tony Skrzypecki is to be interim CFO.
Provident Financial has been embroiled in a hostile takeover battle with John van Kuffeler's Non-Standard Finance, 
with the two companies trading barbs over the past few months. Van Kuffeler was CEO of Provident between 1991 
to 2013.
Non-Standard Finance said it has received bid acceptances from over 50% of Provident shareholders, but added 
that 90% of acceptances is required for success. 
In response, Provident reiterated its rejection of the Non-Standard Finance offer and said it continues to explore 
alternatives to maximise shareholder value.
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Edinburgh Woolen Mills' Day Bids For Bonmarche
Ryanair Holdings reported an increase in traffic for the month of March, with passenger numbers up 9% to 10.9 
million. On a rolling annual basis Ryanair's traffic was up 9% to 142.1 million. 
Smaller budget airline Wizz Air Holdings said it expects its annual profit to come in towards the top of its guidance, 
while also reporting traffic growth in March. 
Wizz Air Holdings said trading in the fourth quarter of its financial year ended on Sunday is in line with expectations. 
The central and eastern Europe-focused airline expects to deliver a net annual profit for the year in the upper half of 
its guidance range of between EUR270 million and EUR300 million. 
HSBC took a downbeat view of the airline sector, downgrading its ratings on easyJet, Ryanair and Wizz Air to Hold 
from Buy. 
Irish building materials firm CRH said it completed the fourth phase of its share buyback programme, returning a 
further EUR200 million of cash to shareholders. The company added that this brings total cash returned to 
shareholders under our share buyback programme to approximately EUR1 billion over the last 12 months.
CRH added that further share buybacks are "under active consideration".
Construction firm Galliford Try said it signed an agreement with Homes England to build more than 850 homes 
across the UK.
The housebuilder said the partnership will deliver housing across key sites in Redcar, Cheshire, Staffordshire and 
Dorset. The homes will be constructed as part of Homes England's initiative to build new housing at pace. 
Construction work will begin on the projects immediately with the first planning applications due to be submitted 
later in April and the first homes expected to be completed in spring 2020.
Miner BHP Group will be reviewing its 2019 production guidance following disruption caused by Cyclone Veronica 
in Australia.
The storm has not caused any major damage at Port Hedland in Western Australia, BHP said, but flooding has 
hampered the movement of trains. As a result, Port Hedland, part of BHP's iron ore arm, is operating at a reduced 
rate and will continue to do so until later in April.
BHP said an early estimate of the impact will see 2019 production fall by around 6 million to 8 million tonnes, and it 
is also reviewing unit cost guidance. A further update will be provided after further work is carried out, it said.
Spectre Holdings, a Dubai-registered company 100% owned by Edinburgh Woolen Mill owner Philip Day, has made 
a mandatory cash offer for clothing retailer Bonmarche after taking a 52.4% stake. The offer values Bonmarche at 
GBP5.7 million, against its GBP8.7 million current market value. Spectre pointed to a significant decline in 
Bonmarche's profitability and said it could offer advice and support.
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index ended flat. In China, the Shanghai Composite is up 0.7%, while the Hang Seng 
index in Hong Kong is up 0.2%.
In the US on Monday, Wall Street ended higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite 
both up 1.3%, while the S&P 500 ended 1.2% higher.
"Rebounding US manufacturing helped US shares advance at the start of the new quarter. The S&P 500 surged to 
its highest level since October while stocks across Asia also rallied on Tuesday, setting European indices up for a 
positive start," said London Capital Group's Jasper Lawler.
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Edinburgh Woolen Mills' Day Bids For Bonmarche
On Monday, a report from the Institute for Supply Management unexpectedly showing a faster rate of growth in US 
manufacturing activity in the month of March.
Additionally on Monday, data showed Chinese manufacturing activity unexpectedly grew for the first time in four 
months in March. A private survey also showed the manufacturing sector in the world's second-biggest economy 
returning to expansion.
"Traders are growing increasingly optimistic that the world's two largest economies are starting to stabilise, amid 
better recent data prints," Lawler said.
The pound was quoted at USD1.3065 early Tuesday, down from USD1.3118 at the London equities close Monday.
UK Prime Minister Theresa May will seek to break the Brexit deadlock as she gathers her Cabinet for a marathon 
session of crisis talks in Downing Street.
The prime minister and her senior ministers will take stock after members of Parliament again failed to find a 
majority for a series of alternatives to her Brexit deal.
A call for a customs union with the EU was rejected by just three votes, while a demand for a second referendum 
was defeated by 12 and a Norway-style deal put forward by Nick Boles by 21.
To cap a dramatic day in the Commons, Boles immediately declared that he would no longer sit as a Conservative 
MP, blaming the party for refusing to compromise on a means of leaving the EU.
Cabinet will meet on Tuesday for five hours to thrash out a way forward.
In Tuesday's economic calendar, the UK's construction PMI is at 0930 BST while eurozone producer prices are at 
1000 BST and US durable goods orders are at 1330 BST.
At 0800 BST, Kantar releases its latest grocery share figures for the 12 weeks ending March 24.

IN THE KNOW: Material Risk To easyJet Consensus After Cautious Outlook
IN THE KNOW: Material Risk To easyJet Consensus After Cautious Outlook
Alliance News
April 1, 2019 Monday 09:56 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 362 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Liberum said it sees as much as a 20% downside risk to consensus forecasts following 
easyJet's downbeat outlook for the second half. 
Shares in the low-cost airline were down 7.6% at 1,033.10 pence on Monday, the worst performer in the FTSE 100 
index. 
For the six months ended March, easyJet expects to report a headline pretax loss of around GBP275 million. This 
compares to a headline loss of GBP18 million a year ago, though it would be an improvement on the GBP299 
million forecast by Liberum.
Most other metrics were in line with management guidance, with a 7.4% decline in revenue per seat at constant 
currency. 
"The outlook is the challenge, with management having less confidence on H2 (summer)," said Liberum. 
Despite the in-line first half, easyJet said it expects revenue per seat at constant currency "slightly up" in the second 
half, reflecting a weakening third quarter demand amid "many unanswered questions" surrounding Brexit.
"Given this uncertainty our outlook for the second half is now more cautious," the airline added.
The guidance assumes a resolution to Brexit uncertainty in the current financial year, Liberum commented, which 
would suggest further downside risk if the political deadlock continues. 
Liberum said it sees at 15% to 20% risks to consensus estimates for the current financial year.
Though UBS did not specify figures, the Swiss bank similarly said it sees "material downside pressure" to forecast 
consensus numbers following the warning. 
IN THE KNOW: Material Risk To easyJet Consensus After Cautious Outlook
The last time easyJet updated the market it seemed cautiously confident, said UBS, so Monday's warning comes 
as a surprise. 
UBS continued to rate the shares at Neutral, holding a 1,310p price target, though the bank sees "material" share 
price pressure. Liberum, meanwhile, kept its Hold rating with a 1,350p price target. 
Other London-listed airlines traded lower on Monday following the warning from easyJet, with British Airways owner 
International Consolidate Airlines down 1.6%, central and eastern Europe-focused Wizz Air down 3.9% and budget 
flier Ryanair down 3.5%.
By Lucy Heming; lucyheming@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.

TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
Alliance News
March 22, 2019 Friday 08:09 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 254 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - easyJet PLC on Friday said it continues to "stand ready" to activate its no-deal Brexit 
contingency plan which will see the suspension of some shareholders' rights. 
The FTSE 100 budget airline said that in the case of a disorderly exit of the UK from the European Union, it will 
suspend the voting rights of a "small number of shares". This will be done to shares held by non-EU shareholders, 
including UK nationals, on a last-in-first-out basis. 
For the period of suspension, the affected shareholders will not be permitted to attend, speak or vote at meeting of 
the company. 
The plan is needed to ensure easyJet's compliance with EU ownership and control requirements, to allow the airline 
to continue flying across the bloc. 
Currently, easyJet's EU ownership, excluding the UK, stands at 49.9%, below the 50% plus 1 share which will be 
required after Brexit to comply with EU rules. 
Earlier in March, airline peer Ryanair Holdings PLC implemented a similar plan among its resolutions to protect the 
company in the case of a no-deal Brexit. 
Ryanair decided that all shares held by non-EU shareholders, including UK ones after Brexit, will be treated as 
"restricted shares", meaning that they will have no entitlement to attend, speak or vote at any company meeting. 
Furthermore, Ryanair added that the prohibition on non-EU nationals to acquire shares, announced in 2002, 
continues to apply. 
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
TOP NEWS: easyJet Ready To Suspend Investor Rights In No-Deal Brexit
Load-Date: March 22, 2019

TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
Alliance News
March 18, 2019 Monday 2:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 292 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - easyJet PLC on Monday said it withdrew from the process of forming a consortium for 
the potential acquisition of Italian flag carrier Alitalia Societa Aerea Italiana Spa. 
The budget airline said it took this decision following discussions with Italy's Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane and US's 
Delta Air Lines, the other two potential members of the consortium.
Ferrovie dello Stato is a state-owned company that manages the Italian rail network, while Delta is an Atlanta, 
Georgia-based airline. 
"easyJet remains committed to Italy, as a key market for the company, where it currently carries 18.5 million 
passengers every year and employs 1400 pilots and crew, all on local contracts," the budget airline said. 
Back in February, easyJet confirmed talks for the potential acquisition of the beleaguered Italian airline.
At the end of October, easyJet submitted a proposal expressing interest in Alitalia after the Italian government was 
forced to rescue the company in 2017.
Alitalia went into government-controlled administration in 2017 and was kept afloat by Italian state loans worth 
EUR900 million. The Italian government was supposed to recoup the money by December 15, 2018 and wrap up 
bankruptcy procedures; however it decided to extend the loan to June 30, 2019.
Back in June 2018, both easyJet and fellow budget operator Ryanair Holdings PLC expresses interest in acquiring 
Alitalia, with the latter backing out following chaos caused by strikes and flights cancellations.
easyJet already flies to many destinations in Italy, including Rome, Milan and Naples.
easyjet shares were trading down 0.8% at 1,249.00 pence each.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
TOP NEWS: easyJet Withdraws Process To Explore Alitalia Acquisition
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: March 18, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair To Block Britons From Buying Shares After "Hard Brexit Day"
Ryanair To Block Britons From Buying Shares After "Hard Brexit Day"
Alliance News
March 11, 2019 Monday 09:20 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 163 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday said its board took steps to protect the company 
from a "hard Brexit" and ensure it will remain majority EU-owned and controlled. 
The budget Irish airline's board implemented a series of resolutions to protect the company in the case of a no-deal 
Brexit. 
Among these, Ryanair decided that all shares held by non-EU shareholders, including British ones after Brexit, will 
be treated as "restricted shares", meaning that they will have no entitlement to attend, speak or vote at any 
company meeting. 
Furthermore, Ryanair added that the prohibition on non-EU nationals to acquire shares, announced in 2002, 
continues to apply.  
"Consequently, with effect from hard Brexit day, UK nationals will not be permitted to acquire ordinary shares in the 
company," it said. 
Ryanair shares were trading down 1.4% at EUR12.00. 
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: March 11, 2019
End of Document
JPMorgan Global Growth & Income Hurt By ASOS , Ryanair , And EA Holdings
JPMorgan Global Growth & Income Hurt By ASOS, Ryanair, And EA 
Holdings
Alliance News
March 7, 2019 Thursday 6:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 303 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - JPMorgan Global Growth & Income PLC on Thursday said it underperformed against 
its benchmark in the first half of its year due to stock selection.
The investment trust posted a net asset value total return for the six months to December of minus 8.6%, lagging 
behind its benchmark - the MSCI All Countries World Index in sterling terms - which had a return of minus 5.7%.
The company's holdings in fashion retailer ASOS PLC, video game firm Electronic Arts Inc, and budget airline 
Ryanair Holdings PLC, were the largest detractors.
The company's NAV declined to 285.6 pence per share on December 31 from 318.4p per share on June 30 and 
323.7p per share year-on-year. 
Shares in JPMorgan Global Growth & Income closed down 0.3% at 306.00 pence on Thursday.
Jeroen Huysinga and Tim Woodhouse, the trust's investment managers, said: "Our high conviction stock picking 
has frequently been a key driver of the company's outperformance of its index, so it is disappointing that stock 
picking was the primary reason for underperformance in 2018."
The company declared a third interim dividend of 3.12p per share for its year ended June 30, up 2.6% from 3.04p 
for the year-ago period.
Huysinga is to depart the company, after over 10 years as its portfolio manager, in order to pursue a masters 
degree and role in the non-profit sector.
Trust Chair Nigel Wightman said: "Jeroen will continue to support the team over the course of the summer to 
ensure a smooth transition. The investment process for the company's portfolio management will remain 
unchanged. The board would like to thank Jeroen for his stewardship of the Company's portfolio during the past ten 
years and wishes him all the best for the future."
JPMorgan Global Growth & Income Hurt By ASOS , Ryanair , And EA Holdings
By Anna Farley; annafarley@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved. 
Load-Date: March 7, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair Found In "Serious Violation" Of Italian Labour Laws
Ryanair Found In "Serious Violation" Of Italian Labour Laws
Alliance News
March 6, 2019 Wednesday 1:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 166 words
Body
ROME (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC has breached Italian labour laws by evading social security and 
bonus payments for its airport staff, according to Italy's labour inspection agency.
"Serious violations" were documented during the course of 2014 at more than a dozen Italian airports served by the 
low-cost Irish airline, the agency said in a statement.
Ryanair was accused of having made "illicit recourse" to about 600 third-party workers to save on insurance, 
pension and bonus payments it would have had to pay to in-house staff.
The illegal conduct took place at airports in Bari, Bergamo, Pisa, Rome, Brindisi, Cagliari, Catania, Lamezia Terme, 
Milan Malpensa, Palermo, Pescara, Alghero and Trapani, according to the agency.
The airline was asked to pay EUR9.2 million in unpaid labour charges and fines, and investigators said they are 
now probing Ryanair's labour practices in the years following 2014.
Ryanair shares were trading up 0.2% in London on Wednesday at EUR12.77.
Copyright dpa
Load-Date: March 6, 2019
End of Document
TOP NEWS: Ryanair And Wizz Air Both Report Traffic Growth In February
TOP NEWS: Ryanair And Wizz Air Both Report Traffic Growth In February
Alliance News
March 4, 2019 Monday 08:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 276 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Budget airline Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday said its traffic grew in February, while 
smaller peer Wizz Air Holdings PLC experienced an even sharper rise.
Ryanair said its February passengers totalled 9.6 million, up 13% from 8.6 million passengers a year before. 
Excluding Austrian subsidiary Laudamotion, Ryanair's passengers increased 9% to 9.3 million. 
Ryanair reported its February load factor came in at 96% in total and for the core airline, while Laudamotion had a 
load factor of 94%. Ryanair previously had reported a 95% load factor for February 2018.
Ryanair said it operated 53,000 flights in February, of which 93% arrived on time. According to the company, this 
meant that it delivered "the best punctuality of any major EU airline" for the period.
On a rolling annual basis, Ryanair's traffic was up 8.8% to 141.2 million from 129.8 million.
Wizz Air, meanwhile, posted a 14% increase in passenger traffic to 2.4 million from 2.1 million the year before. On a 
rolling annual basis, traffic rose 18% to 34.3 million from 29.1 million.
Wizz Air's load factor increased 3.0 percentage points to 94.2% from 91.2% year-on-year and its capacity increased 
to 2.5 million seats from 2.3 million.
Wizz Air said it continued to grow its network in February, with five new routes announced and the expansion of its 
fleet with a new Airbus A321, bringing its total fleet to 108 aircraft.
Shares in Ryanair were down 0.1% at EUR12.66 in London on Monday morning, while Wizz Air shares were up 
0.7% in the FTSE 250 at 3,059.60 pence.
By Paul McGowan; paulmcgowan@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved. 
TOP NEWS: Ryanair And Wizz Air Both Report Traffic Growth In February
Load-Date: March 4, 2019
End of Document
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Higher Call On Hopes Of US -China Trade Deal
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Higher Call On Hopes Of US-China Trade 
Deal
Alliance News
March 4, 2019 Monday 07:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 449 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are seen opening higher on Monday, tracking strong gains in 
Asia, amid optimism that a trade deal between the US and China is within sight. 
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index will open 26.37 points higher at 7,133.10. The blue chip index closed 2.00 
points, or 0.5%, at 7,106.73 Friday. 
Sentiment was given a boost after the Wall Street Journal over the weekend reported that the US and China are 
close to reaching a trade deal that could lift US tariffs on imports from China. The newspaper said China is offering 
to lower tariffs on US products in categories ranging from farms to chemicals and autos.
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 1.0% in response. In China, the Shanghai Composite is up 1.1%, while 
the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong is up 0.7%.
"After months of trade tensions, the world's two largest economies are reportedly nearing a trade deal which would 
remove US tariffs on Chinese imports," said London Capital Group's Jasper Lawler.
"Markets are a sea of green as the new week kicks off. Trade deal optimism sent Asian markets sharply higher, 
whilst European and US futures are pointing to a strong start out of the blocks on the opening bell."
In the US on Friday, Wall Street ended higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4%, S&P 500 up 0.7% 
and Nasdaq Composite up 0.8%.
The pound was quoted at USD1.3232 early Monday, marginally higher from USD1.3222 at the London equities 
close Friday. 
In political news, UK Prime Minister Theresa May was given a Brexit boost as key Tories signalled swinging behind 
her stance in exchange for movement on the Northern Irish backstop.
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Higher Call On Hopes Of US -China Trade Deal
Chairman of the influential 1922 Committee of backbench Tories Graham Brady expressed optimism that a 
breakthrough on the backstop was close.
The hardline European Research Group of Tory MPs led by Jacob Rees-Mogg also indicated a more conciliatory 
tone on the issue.
The ERG has drawn up "three tests" the government must pass to win backing, according to the Sunday Times.
A light economic events calendar on Monday has eurozone producer prices at 1000 GMT.
On Thursday this week, the European Central Bank will announce its latest interest rate decision. The central bank 
is widely expected to keep monetary policy unchanged. 
On Friday, there is the US jobs report for February due. 
The UK corporate calendar on Monday has full-year results from valve actuators manufacturer Rotork, speciality 
chemicals company Synthomer, engineer Senior and geotechnical contractor Keller Group. Also due are February 
traffic statistics from Ryanair.
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: March 4, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair Shifts Spare Parts From UK To EU Countries Ahead Of Brexit
Ryanair Shifts Spare Parts From UK To EU Countries Ahead Of Brexit
Alliance News
March 2, 2019 Saturday 12:46 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 138 words
Body
BERLIN (Alliance News) - Europe's biggest budget airline is taking precautions in case of a no-deal Brexit by 
shifting some of its spare parts from a British central storage unit to other EU locations.
Ryanair Holdings PLC's director of maintenance and engineering told dpa that an unregulated departure by the UK 
from the EU could make moving parts around difficult because of customs restrictions, for example.
"We're concerned that it could take longer to get spare parts to airports where we need them quickly from the 
central storage in Stansted," Karsten Muehlenfeld said, referring to the London airport.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary is an outspoken critic of Brexit, though he says his Irish airline, which is registered in 
the EU and not in Britain, will not be as badly affected as some British-based airlines.
Copyright dpa
Load-Date: March 2, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Includes Pay Allowances In Agreement With German Pilot Union
Ryanair Includes Pay Allowances In Agreement With German Pilot Union
Alliance News
March 1, 2019 Friday 6:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 91 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Friday said it had reached an agreement with the German 
pilot union, Vereinigung Cockpit, on pay and allowances for a period of four years.
The Irish budget airline said the agreement will be included in a collective labour deal that is expected to be 
finalised between Ryanair and Vereinigung Cockpit before the end of March. 
Ryanair shares closed 4.7% higher on Friday at EUR12.68 each.
By Evelina Grecenko; evelinagrecenko@alliancenews.com
