Italy Regulator Fines Ryanair, Wizz Air For Hand-Luggage Restrictions
Italy Regulator Fines Ryanair, Wizz Air For Hand-Luggage Restrictions
Alliance News
February 22, 2019 Friday 06:26 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 106 words
Body
ROME (Alliance News) - Low cost airlines Ryanair Holdings PLC and Wizz Air Holdings PLC were fined by Italy's 
antitrust regulator on Thursday for their hand-luggage restrictions.
The Italian Competition Authority said extra charges for larger carry-on bags, which the two airlines introduced last 
year, represented an unfair trade practice.
Being able to take on board a reasonably sized bag as part of the standard air fare is an "essential service" that 
should not be subject to additional fees, AGCM said.
It fined Ryanair EUR3 million and Wizz Air EUR1 million. Both companies were given 60 days to change their 
luggage policy.
Copyright dpa
Load-Date: February 22, 2019
End of Document
UPDATE: Belgian Ryanair Pilots Vote For Collective Labour Agreement
UPDATE: Belgian Ryanair Pilots Vote For Collective Labour Agreement
Alliance News
February 20, 2019 Wednesday 3:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 333 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Wednesday confirmed that 98% of its directly employed pilots 
based in Belgium have voted in favour of a four-year collective labour agreement governing their pay and 
conditions.
The agreement was negotiated between the budged airline and unions BeCa, CNE-CSC, and LBC-NVK.
Earlier in the day, Ryanair confirmed 98% of its directly employed pilots based in Belgium had voted in favour of a 
recognition agreement with BeCa, to cover all of Ryanair's directly employed pilots in Belgium.
The airline and BeCA were said to be progressing a collective labour agreement which they both hoped to conclude 
before the end of April. 
Ryanair has been talking with unions across Europe in regards to collective labour agreements. In January, the 
company said it is working on a recognition agreement with the SITCPLA and USO unions in Spain. In November, it 
recognised Portuguese union SNPVAC, and the same month signed a labour agreement covering all German cabin 
crews.
It has also signed similar agreements with Italian crews, and has been in talks with Greek and Swedish staff. 
In addition, on Wednesday Ryanair also said it will open a new base at Toulouse, France in October with two 
aircraft and 11 new routes.
The Irish airline said the new routes includes flights to Alicante and Valencia in Spain, Porto in Portugal, 
Luxembourg, Budapest in Hungary, Palermo in Italy, Tangier and Oujda in Morocco, and Brest, Lille and Marseille 
in France.
"We are delighted to announce a USD200 million aircraft investment at Ryanair's third French base in Toulouse 
airport, which will deliver 1 million customers per annum, create 60 Ryanair pilot and cabin crew jobs and support 
750 airport jobs," said Ryanair Chief Commercial Officer David O'Brien.
UPDATE: Belgian Ryanair Pilots Vote For Collective Labour Agreement
Ryanair shares were trading 0.4% higher on Wednesday at EUR11.95 each.
By Evelina Grecenko; evelinagrecenko@alliancenews.com
Anna Farley; annafarley@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 20, 2019
End of Document
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Invests USD200 Million To Launch New Base In France
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Invests USD200 Million To Launch New Base In France
Alliance News
February 20, 2019 Wednesday 2:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 279 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Wednesday said it will open a new base at Toulouse, France, 
in October with two aircraft and 11 new routes.
The Irish budget airline said the new routes includes flights to Alicante and Valencia in Spain, Porto in Portugal, 
Luxembourg, Budapest in Hungary, Palermo in Italy, Tangier and Oujda in Morocco, and Brest, Lille and Marseille 
in France.
"We are delighted to announce a USD200 million aircraft investment at Ryanair's third French base in Toulouse 
airport, which will deliver 1 million customers per annum, create 60 Ryanair pilot and cabin crew jobs and support 
750 airport jobs," said Ryanair Chief Commercial Officer David O'Brien.
In addition, Ryanair has confirmed that 98% of its directly employed pilots based in Belgium have voted in favour of 
a recognition agreement with BeCA, to cover all of Ryanair's directly employed pilots in Belgium.
The airline and BeCA are now progressing a collective labour agreement, the company said, which they both hope 
to conclude before the end of April. 
Ryanair has been talking with unions across Europe in regards to collective labour agreements. In January, the 
company said it is working on a recognition agreement with the SITCPLA and USO unions in Spain. In November, it 
recognised Portuguese union SNPVAC, and the same month signed a labour agreement covering all German cabin 
crews.
It has also signed similar agreements with Italian crews, and has been in talks with Greek and Swedish staff. 
Ryanair shares were trading 1.7% higher on Wednesday at EUR12.10 each.

IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Will Soar In Peak Summer Season - SocGen
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Will Soar In Peak Summer Season - SocGen
Alliance News
February 19, 2019 Tuesday 2:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1084 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Societe Generale took an upbeat view on the airline sector heading into the key 
summer season of 2019 deeming Ryanair as a stock to watch out for, but was mindful over the blue chip airline 
operator amid Brexit uncertainty. 
SocGen's Michael Kuhn and Sumit Mehrotra said 2018 proved to be a challenging year for the airline sector with 
high capacity, air traffic control issues and rising oil prices turning out to be a "toxic mix".
However, the analysts said the prospects for 2019 appear more upbeat with oil prices coming down from multi-year 
highs and capacity growth set to not be as excessive.
"Lower crude prices, still more frequencies and new city-pair additions should help support demand in 2019. But 
with our economists forecasting GDP growth easing across the eurozone this year, it is still unclear whether the 
multiplier will fall further and demand growth will slow, which would put EU airline profitability under pressure from 
the risk of capacity additions outpacing demand in 2019," Kuhn and Mehrotra said. 
As such, the analysts said investors should pick airlines that have a strong long-term track record, proven crisis 
resistance and limited Brexit risk, and that Ryanair embodies these qualities. 
SocGen upgraded the Irish carrier to Buy from Hold and raised its price target to EUR14 from EUR12.80. Ryanair 
shares were up 1.7% at EUR11.97 on Tuesday.
Kuhn and Mehrotra acknowledged that the last 18 months have been difficult for Ryanair with pilot rostering issues 
and a slew of profit warnings.
In late 2017, Ryanair came under fire over a rostering failure leading to thousands of flights being cancelled and a 
number of routes suspended - triggered a company-wide wave of unionisations. The outcome led to Ryanair having 
to pay sharply higher wages to its employees. 
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Will Soar In Peak Summer Season - SocGen
In January, the airline issued its second profit warning in four months, as it said airfares were falling more than 
expected over the winter.
However, the analysts took a positive stance on Ryanair saying its woes are now behind it. 
"After a negotiation marathon that Ryanair's management had to go through over the past year, most union issues 
have been resolved and the strike risk for Ryanair  has mostly dissipated. We think some of the new contractual 
agreements will somewhat trim Ryanair's flexibility, but we think its business model is far from being broken. We 
maintain our view that short-haul aviation is an increasingly commoditised business and that the lowest-cost 
operators will prevail in that segment in the long term," the pair said. 
In October, Ryanair also cut its annual profit guidance and was cautious over its outlook due to air-strikes higher oil 
prices and as economic uncertainties persist. 
"Even in an adverse scenario, we think Ryanair would be among the best airline stocks to hold, as industry 
consolidation would likely accelerate. Ryanair has also stated that it would reinitiate share buybacks once the 
outcome of Brexit is known (if it is not a hard Brexit)," Kuhn and Mehrotra said.
Turning to the FTSE 100, SocGen said easyJet and International Consolidated Airlines Group are prone to Brexit 
related risks. 
SocGen reiterated its Hold rating on easyJet and kept its price target at 1,270p. The stock was down 0.7% at 
1,273.50p Tuesday.
Kuhn and Mehrotra noted that easyJet has many positive qualities that an airline operator should possess, think the 
market is overestimating the company's earnings growth capabilities.
"The company is fundamentally sound, with close to GBP400 million net cash as of year-end 2018. However, 
easyJet's profile is now a more defensive than growth-oriented: its network is built on leading positions at capacity-
constrained prime airports, a strong brand, and a loyal customer base. While its cost base is not the lowest, we 
think it is probably the best in the value-for-money category," the analysts said. 
Moreover, the analysts said the biggest risk to easyJet is that a hard Brexit may trigger a short-term EU-UK air 
traffic shutdown.
"That said, we think a hard Brexit could have a 'silver lining' for easyJet in structural terms by accelerating 
consolidation across the airline industry. However, such a shakeout could take may years, putting a cap on 
earnings growth for longer. Compared with its low-cost peers Ryanair and Wizz Air, easyJet remains more 
dependent on the UK market," Kuhn and Mehrotra said. 
SocGen reiterated its Hold rating on IAG and kept its price target at 650p. The stock was down 0.8% at 644.80p 
Tuesday.
The analyst said IAG shares have recovered from the Brexit referendum outcome and has continued to deliver 
growth and margin improvement. Moreover, the British Airways and Iberia parent company is almost free of 
financial net debt.
Kuhn and Mehrotra highlighted that a hard Brexit would be detrimental for IAG as it would heighten regulatory and 
macroeconomic risks.
"Ownership remains a major challenge for IAG, as it would need to prove to regulators that BA's ownership and 
control is British, while Iberia's is Spanish. Senior EU officials have doubted that IAG's structure allows for that. The 
EU will give airlines a seven-month period to overhaul their shareholder structure, as the FT reported earlier this 
month. This is enough time, in our view, but might still trigger significant forced selling, as IAG's EU ownership 
excluding the UK might be as low as 25%," the pair said. 
IN THE KNOW: Ryanair Will Soar In Peak Summer Season - SocGen
SocGen downgraded Wizz Air to Hold from Buy saying the eastern Europe-focused airline is one of the best 
structurally positioned airlines in the sector, but its strengths seem to be adequately reflected in the share price.
The French bank cut its price target to 3,450p from 3,550p. Wizz Air shares were down 0.6% at 3,222.00p Tuesday. 
"Wizz Air remains one of the most interesting long-term stories in aviation, and the arrival of the A321neos in the 
fleet should help it to keep unit costs under control. However, at around 14.5 times 2020 price-to-earnings ratio, it is 
among the most expensive European airline stocks, and has outperformed most peers over the last 12 months," the 
analysts said.
However, Kuhn and Mehrotra said Wizz Air and Ryanir are the only carriers with strong medium-to long-term 
growth prospects in the central and eastern Europe market.
Moreover, the CEE region continues to deliver the highest growth rates in Europe, which should continue to favour 
Wizz Air, the pair added. 
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 19, 2019
End of Document

LONDON (Alliance News) - Wizz Air Holdings PLC on Tuesday said Chief Commercial Officer George 
Michalopoulos sold 5,000 shares at GBP32.30 each on Monday.

Shares in Wizz Air were down 0.6% at 3,224.00p on Tuesday.
Also on Tuesday, French investment bank Societe Generale SA cut its Wizz Air rating to Hold from Buy, while 
raising competitor airline Ryanair Holdings PLC to Buy from Hold.
In early February, Wizz Air reported an 8.3% increase in January passenger numbers to 2.6 million from 2.4 million

TOP NEWS: easyJet Confirms Talks For Potential Alitalia Acquisition
TOP NEWS: easyJet Confirms Talks For Potential Alitalia Acquisition
Alliance News
February 14, 2019 Thursday 08:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - easyJet PLC on Thursday confirmed it is in talks with Italy's Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane 
Spa and the US's Delta Air Lines Inc in order to form a consortium to explore options regarding the future of 
beleaguered Italian airline Alitalia Societa Aerea Italiana Spa. 
Ferrovie dello Stato is a state-owned company that manages the Italian rail network, while Delta is an Atlanta, 
Georgia-based airline.  
At the end of October, easyJet submitted a proposal expressing interest in Alitalia after the Italian government was 
forced to rescue the Italian flag carrier in 2017.
Alitalia went into government-controlled administration in 2017 and was kept afloat by Italian state loans worth 
EUR900 million. The Italian government was supposed to recoup the money by December 15, 2018 and wrap up 
bankruptcy procedures; however it decided to extend the loan to June 30, 2019.
Back in June 2018, both easyJet and fellow budget operator Ryanair Holdings PLC expresses interest in acquiring 
Alitalia, with the latter backing out following chaos caused by strikes and flights cancellations.
easyJet already flies to many destinations in Italy, including Rome, Milan and Naples. 
easyJet shares were trading up 0.4% at 1,287.10 pence each.  
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 14, 2019
TOP NEWS: easyJet Confirms Talks For Potential Alitalia Acquisition

CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Brace For Turbulence Ahead
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Brace For Turbulence 
Ahead
Alliance News
February 8, 2019 Friday 12:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1313 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Airlines and travel operators had a busy week as both TUI and Thomas Cook warned 
on lower margins, Ryanair swung to a loss and easyJet stepped up Brexit preparations.
In other key retail and consumer services news, Ocado reported a fire at one of its robotic warehouse, while data 
showed increases in both UK retail and grocery sales. 
Travel and airline operator TUI, in a surprise trading update, said that the out-of-the-ordinary hot weather in the 
summer resulted in later bookings, weakening margins. It also said continued weakness in Sterling made it difficult 
to improve margins.
TUI said that annual earnings for its current financial year will be "broadly stable" on last year due to "extraordinary" 
hot weather and the weakness of the pound.
For the year ending September 30, the company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and 
amortisation to be broadly stable on the record performance in the prior year of EUR1.17 billion.
As a result of the "broadly stable" earnings guidance, the FTSE100 listed company said it will be unable to meet its 
guidance of at least 10% compound annual growth rate in underlying Ebitda at constant currency for the three years 
to 2020 financial year.
Similarly, on Thursday rival Thomas Cook also reported a year-on-year fall in first quarter gross margins due to cut 
throat competitive market in the UK and weak demand for winter holidays in the Nordics. 
The company also announced a strategic review of its airline business, which could potentially lead to a sale.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Brace For Turbulence Ahead
"As expected, the knock-on effect from the prolonged summer heatwave and high prices in the Canaries have 
impacted customer demand for winter sun," Thomas Cook Chief Executive Peter Fankhauser said.
Thomas Cook's revenue for the first quarter to end of 2018 rose 1% to GBP1.66 billion but the company's adjusted 
operating loss widened by GBP14 million to GBP60 million.
TUI shares were trading down 2.1% at 934.80 pence each on Friday, while Thomas Cook was down 16% at 
28.64p, retreating from gains made on Thursday. 
In the budget airlines sector, Ryanair announced changes to its corporate structure after posting a third-quarter loss 
and warning of lower annual profit.
The Irish airliner on Monday said that over the next 12 months it will move to a group structure "not dissimilar" to 
that of rival and British Airways parent International Consolidated Airlines Group PLC.
Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team will oversee the development of four airline 
subsidiaries. Chief Executive Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. O'Leary 
committed to further five years at the head of the company.
Ryanair said its third-quarter results to the end of 2018 were "disappointing", with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 
million pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago.
Revenue increased 9% in the third quarter to EUR1.53 billion from EUR1.41 billion on the back of higher customer 
numbers, up to 32.7 million from 30.4 million a year ago.
Looking ahead, Ryanair expects annual profit to be between EUR1.0 billion and EUR1.1 billion, down up to 31% 
from comparative period, due to lower winter fares but better-than-expected cost performance in the second half. 
The company posted a profit of EUR1.45 billion for 2017 financial year.
With regards to Brexit, Ryanair - which had previously warned on the "underestimated" risk of a no-deal - said it has 
taken all the "necessary steps" to protect the company.
With Brexit just 49 days away, peer easyJet on Thursday also said it increased its EU ownership to 49% in order to 
be able to continue flying in Europe after the UK's exit from the European Union in March.
easyJet said it remains confident of its ability to continue flying whatever the outcome, as it has "undertaken 
significant preparations" since the vote of the referendum was delivered.
One of the major news in the retail sector this week was delivered by online grocer Ocado. 
Ocado on Tuesday reported a widened annual loss and a major fire at one of its warehouses. The company's 
earnings were hampered by higher operating costs in a year of major expansion that saw the online grocer ink 
several significant deals.
For the financial year to December 2, 2018, revenue rose by 9.9% to GBP1.59 billion from GBP1.45 billion a year 
prior, on the back of an increase in average number of orders a week and fees from partnerships.
However, Ocado's pretax loss came in at GBP44.4 million, widened from GBP8.3 million a year prior. Financial 
2017 results were restated after the adoption of new accounting rule IFRS15, last year the grocer had reported a 
GBP1.0 million profit.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Brace For Turbulence Ahead
The pretax loss was significantly wider than analysts expectations, which had forecast Ocado's loss at GBP30.0 
million. 
During the year, Ocado inked deals with US retailer Kroger, Swedish supermarket group ICA, France's Groupe 
Casino and in Canada with Sobeys, as retailers lined-up to secure UK company's cutting-edge technology, which 
includes robots in warehouses.
Looking ahead, the online grocer said that, if economic conditions "remain broadly stable", it expects to achieving 
Retail revenue growth of between 10￿15% in financial 2019 as it prepares to increase its fulfilment capacity and 
grow market share in the UK.
Retail Ebitda is expected to grow, as the increased use of automated warehouses, called customer fulfillment 
centres, brings in cost savings and synergies, Ocado said.
It was at one of this warehouses in Andover, England, that a fire broke on Tuesday, just after the company 
announced its results. 
After continuing to burn overnight, Ocado said that the fire caused "substantial damage" to both the Andover 
building and its contents, as part of the roof collapsed.
"Ocado is working hard to minimise disruption for customers by increasing capacity at other facilities," it added.
Due to the presence of pressurised refrigerants on site causing risk of explosions, the area around the warehouse 
had to be evacuated on Wednesday night. 
Since then, the refrigerants have been removed from the site and the "major incident status" and evacuation have 
been lifted.
Ocado shares were trading up 2.0% at 891.20p each on Friday. On Monday, before news of the fire broke, Ocado 
shares were trading at 1000.50p. 
A wider overlook on the beleaguered retail sector led to a breath of fresh air, as UK retail sales picked up in January 
following the worst December in a decade. 
On Tuesday, the latest BRC-KPMG Retail Sales Monitor figures covering the four weeks to January 26, showed UK 
retail sales up 2.2% from the year before, as heavy discounting tempted cautious shoppers. 
This marked the highest annual growth since June and was above both the 3-month and 12-month averages of 
0.8% and 1.2% respectively. In December, total sales were flat compared to the prior year, marking the worst 
December performance since 2008.
"There was a welcome return to growth this month after December's disappointing sales figures. But while retail 
discounts helped tempt cautious consumers, there is no guarantee this momentum will continue after the sales 
have finished," Chief Executive Officer of the British Retail Consortium Helen Dickinson said.
Supermarkets also had reasons to celebrate this week, as data from Kantar Woldpanel covering the 12 weeks to 
January 27, saw UK grocery sales up 1.7% on the prior year.
However, despite reporting rising sales, all supermarkets, with the exception of Aldi, Lidl and Co-op, saw their 
market share dip on the prior year. The only grocer slipping, in sales, was Sainsbury's with sales down 0.3% during 
the period.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Airlines Brace For Turbulence Ahead
Grocery inflation now stands at 1.3%, Kantar reported, with prices rising since January 2017.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 8, 2019
End of Document
IN THE KNOW: Liberum Says Buy Ryanair Amid Share Price Weakness
IN THE KNOW: Liberum Says Buy Ryanair Amid Share Price Weakness
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 430 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Liberum reiterated its Buy rating on Ryanair Holdings saying the Irish carrier is still the 
"long-term industry winner", despite posting a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit. 
The broker kept its price target at EUR14.50. Ryanair shares were down 2.5% at EUR11.15 on Monday and are 
down 31% over the past 12 months. 
Ryanair also said Monday it will make changes to its corporate structure. Under the proposed changes, a small 
senior management team led by Group CEO Michael O'Leary will oversee the development of four airline 
subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK. 
Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter results to the end of 2018 were "disappointing", swinging to a EUR83.6 
million pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit last year, due to weaker than expected air fares.
The results included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting mostly from the acquisition of Austrian airline Lauda. 
Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair still reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss versus a EUR126.0 million profit a 
year before, due to lower airfares.
Ryanair's third quarter revenue of EUR1.53 billion was lower than Liberum's forecast of EUR1.55 billion 
Liberum's Gerald Khoo said Ryanair's results showed a swing to an anticipated loss in the seasonally second 
weakest quarter of an airline's financial year.
The analyst said that "unsurprisingly" there was no change to the profit guidance of between EUR1.0 billion and 
EUR1.1 billion outlined at its most recent profit warning in January, when it said airfares were falling more than 
expected over the winter.
"Given the ongoing uncertainty over Brexit, and the potential impact on consumer confidence, the balance of short-
term risks remains to the downside. However, we expect attention to turn to next year, where the range of potential 
IN THE KNOW: Liberum Says Buy Ryanair Amid Share Price Weakness
outcome is much wider, but where there may be scope for optimism on more restrained industry capacity growth," 
Khoo said. 
Despite its recent woes, the Liberum analyst said Ryanair remains "the long-term winner in the European airline 
industry", due to its leading market position, extensive network, low unit costs and strong balance sheet. 
"We see tougher market conditions in the short term as positive for the stronger airlines in the long term, since this 
clears out weaker competitors and aids consolidation in the market. We would view short-term share price 
weakness as a buying opportunity," the analyst added. 
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2018 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 4, 2019
End of Document
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Subdued Open; Indivior Sells Interest In China
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Subdued Open; Indivior Sells Interest In 
China
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 07:45 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 867 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are seen opening marginally lower on Monday amid quiet 
trading in Asian markets. 
In early UK corporate news, Irish airline Ryanair announced a reorganisation, drugmaker Indivior divested its 
interests in China, and outsourcer Serco signed a big contract in Australia.
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index is to open 0.52 points lower at 7,019.70. The blue chip index closed up 
51.37 points, or 0.7%, at 7,020.22 on Friday. 
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.5%. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index closed up 0.2% after a half-
day session. Financial markets in China are closed on Monday for Chinese New Year's Eve and will remain closed 
for the rest of the week. Hong Kong's financial markets will be closed Tuesday to Thursday for the Lunar New Year 
holiday.
"Trading in Asia was quiet overnight as celebrations for Chinese New Year kicked off, and Chinese markets remain 
closed. We expect muted trading in Asia across the week, a sharp contrast to recent weeks which have seen US-
Sino trade headlines and China growth concerns drive movement. European and US futures are pointing to a quiet 
start with markets struggling for direction," said London Capital Gtopu's Jasper Lawler. 
The pound was marginally lower, quoted at USD1.3070 early Monday from USD1.3099 at the London equities 
close Friday.
LONDON MARKET PRE-OPEN: Subdued Open; Indivior Sells Interest In China
UK Prime Minister Theresa May will invite rebel Tory members of Parliament into the heart of government on 
Monday to thrash out changes to her Brexit deal she hopes can overcome massive opposition in Brussels and 
Westminster.
Hardline eurosceptics in the European Research Group and Remain-supporting former ministers will form the 
Alternative Arrangements Working Group, which Downing Street said would meet "regularly" with Brexit Secretary 
Stephen Barclay and senior officials.
ERG deputy chairman Steve Baker, former Northern Ireland secretary Owen Paterson and Yeovil MP Marcus Fysh 
will join forces with former education secretary Nicky Morgan and ex-cabinet office minister Damian Green to 
examine the feasibility of the so-called Malthouse Compromise.
FTSE 250 drugmaker Indivior said it is to divest its interest related to the Sai Bo Song drug in China to the Zhejiang 
Pukang Biotechnology Co for USD122.5 million.
"The divestiture of the Sai Bo Song tablet in China is consistent with Indivior's efforts to prioritize efforts on the long-
term growth opportunities with our new depot assets, Sublocade and Perseris," said Shaun Thaxter, chief executive 
officer of Indivior. "This transaction helps us focus our resources on the highest return opportunities in the regions 
we know best, while ensuring patients in China have access to an important and transformational treatment." 
Indivior also said it has signed an agreement with Alvogen Pine Brook prohibiting the US pharmaceutical company 
from distributing or selling its generic buprenorphine and naloxone sublingual film product in the US.
Indivior had been granted a temporary restraining order by the US District Court for the District of New Jersey 
against Alvogen on January 24.
Outsourcer Serco Group said it signed a GBP560 million contract with Bupa Health Services to support the 
Australian Defence Force. The contract has up to four one-year extensions and full operational service under the 
new contract will begin on July 1. Under the contract, Serco will be responsible for providing defence support 
services across more than 50 bases in Australia. Serco will be delivering recruitment, on-boarding, training, 
workforce management and various other employee lifecycle, account management and support functions. 
Ryanair Holdings said it will make changes to its structure as the budget airline reported a swing to third-quarter 
loss and warned of lower annual profit. 
Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team led by Group CEO Michael O'Leary will oversee 
the development of four airline subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK. O'Leary has 
signed a new five-year contract to the lead the company.
Ryanair swung to a EUR83.6 million pretax loss in the third quarter from a EUR112.9 million profit in the 
comparative period a year ago. The company's loss included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting from the acquisition 
of Austrian airline Lauda. Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair still reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss, versus a 
EUR126.0 million profit a year before. 
Wizz Air reported its January load factor improved by 0.4 percentage point to 88.1% and passenger numbers rose 
8.3% to 2.6 million from 2.4 million last year. The central and eastern Europe-focused airline said it expanded its 
network in January with an additional 14 routes announced in Macedonia, Romania and Albania.
Elsewhere, JPMorgan downgraded miner BHP Group to Underweight from Neutral. 
The economic events calendar has UK construction PMI at 0930 GMT. There is also Italy inflation readings and 
eurozone producer prices at 1000 GMT.

In the US earnings calendar on Monday, Google parent Alphabet will report earnings after the market close in New 
York.

TOP NEWS: Ryanair Opts For New Group Structure After Swing To Loss
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Opts For New Group Structure After Swing To Loss
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 07:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 473 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday said it will make changes to its structure after 
swinging to a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit. 
The Irish budget airline said that over the next 12 months it will move to a group structure not dissimilar to that of 
rival International Consolidated Airliners Group PLC, owner of British Airways and Spain's Iberia. 
Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team will oversee the development of four airline 
subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK. 
Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. The company 
will, later this year, appoint a replacement as CEO of Ryanair DAC.
Chair David Bonderman and Senior Independent Director Kyran McLaughlin have agreed to remain on the 
company's board until summer 2020. They will leave after that date. 
"In order to ensure a smooth succession, Stan McCarthy who joined the board in May 2017, has agreed to take up 
the position of deputy chair from April 2019, and will transition to chair of the board in summer 2020," Ryanair 
added. 
Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter results were disappointing, with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 million 
pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago. 
The company's loss included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting from the acquisition of Austrian airline Lauda. 
Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss versus a EUR126.0 million profit a year 
before. 
Revenue rose 9% to EUR1.53 billion from EUR1.41 billion on the back of higher customer numbers, up to 32.7 
million from 30.4 million a year ago. 
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Opts For New Group Structure After Swing To Loss
O'Leary said: "While a EUR20 million loss in the third was disappointing, we take comfort that this was entirely due 
to weaker than expected air fares so our customers are enjoying record low prices, which is good for current and 
future traffic growth."
Ryanair load factor was unchanged compared to the prior year at 96%. 
Looking ahead, Ryanair said that, excluding an expected "heavy" loss from Lauda in its first year of operations, its 
annual profit will come in between EUR1.0 billion and EUR1.1 billion due to lower winter fares but better-than-
expected cost performance in the second half. 
A year ago, Ryanair profit was EUR1.45 billion, so the decline will be as much as 31%. 
"While we have reasonable visibility of our fourth quarter bookings, we cannot rule out further cuts to air fares 
and/or slightly lower full year guidance especially if there are unexpected Brexit and/or security developments which 
adversely impact fares for close-in bookings between now and the end of March," the company added.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 4, 2019
End of Document

LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London are seen opening marginally higher on Monday amid quiet 
trading in Asian markets, while budget airline Ryanair swung to a loss in the third quarter.  
IG futures indicate the FTSE 100 index is to open 7.48 points higher at 7,027.70. The blue chip index closed up 
51.37 points, or 0.7%, at 7,020.22 on Friday. 
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.5% while the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong closed up 0.2%. 
Financial markets in China are closed on Monday for Chinese New Years Eve and will remain closed for the rest of 
the week. 
Hong Kong's financial markets will be closed Tuesday to Thursday.
"Trading in Asia was quiet overnight as celebrations for Chinese New Year kicked off and Chinese markets remain 
closed. We expect muted trading in Asia across the week, a sharp contrast to recent weeks which have seen US-
Sino trade headlines and China growth concerns drive movement. European and US futures are pointing to a quiet 
start with markets struggling for direction," said London Capital Gtopu's Jasper Lawler. 
The pound was marginally lower, quoted at USD1.3070 early Monday from USD1.3099 at the London equities 
close Friday.
UK Prime Minister Theresa May will invite rebel Tory members of Parliament into the heart of government on 
Monday to thrash out changes to her Brexit deal she hopes to overcome massive opposition in Brussels and 
Westminster.

Alternative Arrangements Working Group, which Downing Street said would meet "regularly" with Brexit Secretary 
Stephen Barclay and senior officials.

LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Chief Signs For 5 More Years Amid Restructure
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Chief Signs For 5 More Years Amid Restructure
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 08:02 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1916 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings on Monday said it will make changes to its corporate structure after 
swinging to a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit.
The Irish budget airline said that over the next 12 months it will move to a group structure not dissimilar to that of 
rival International Consolidated Airliners Group PLC, owner of British Airways and Spain's Iberia.
Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team will oversee the development of four airline 
subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK.
Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. The company 
will, later this year, appoint a replacement as CEO of Ryanair DAC. O'Leary also signed a contract for another five 
years as head of the company.
Chair David Bonderman and Senior Independent Director Kyran McLaughlin have agreed to remain on the 
company's board until summer 2020. They will leave after that date.
"In order to ensure a smooth succession, Stan McCarthy who joined the board in May 2017, has agreed to take up 
the position of deputy chair from April 2019, and will transition to chair of the board in summer 2020," Ryanair 
added.
Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter results were disappointing, with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 million 
pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago.
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Chief Signs For 5 More Years Amid Restructure
The company's loss included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting from the acquisition of Austrian airline Lauda. 
Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss versus a EUR126.0 million profit a year 
before.
Revenue rose 9% to EUR1.53 billion from EUR1.41 billion on the back of higher customer numbers, up to 32.7 
million from 30.4 million a year ago.
O'Leary said: "While a EUR20 million loss in the third was disappointing, we take comfort that this was entirely due 
to weaker than expected air fares so our customers are enjoying record low prices, which is good for current and 
future traffic growth."
Ryanair load factor was unchanged compared to the prior year at 96%.
Looking ahead, Ryanair said that, excluding an expected "heavy" loss from Lauda in its first year of operations, its 
annual profit will come in between EUR1.0 billion and EUR1.1 billion due to lower winter fares but better-than-
expected cost performance in the second half.
A year ago, Ryanair profit was EUR1.45 billion, so the decline will be as much as 31%.
"While we have reasonable visibility of our fourth quarter bookings, we cannot rule out further cuts to air fares 
and/or slightly lower full year guidance especially if there are unexpected Brexit and/or security developments which 
adversely impact fares for close-in bookings between now and the end of March," the company added.

UK Prime Minister Theresa May will invite rebel Tory members of Parliament into the heart of government on 
Monday to thrash out changes to her Brexit deal she hopes can overcome massive opposition in Brussels and 
Westminster. Hardline eurosceptics in the European Research Group and Remain-supporting former ministers will 
form the Alternative Arrangements Working Group, which Downing Street said would meet "regularly" with Brexit 
Secretary Stephen Barclay and senior officials. ERG deputy chairman Steve Baker, former Northern Ireland 
secretary Owen Paterson and Yeovil MP Marcus Fysh will join forces with former education secretary Nicky Morgan 
and ex-cabinet office minister Damian Green to examine the feasibility of the so-called Malthouse Compromise.
----------
Japanese car maker Nissan Motor said it plans to switch production of a new SUV model from Britain to Japan, 
dealing another blow to the British government's post-Brexit economic plans. Nissan said it cancelled plans to 
produce the X-Trail model at its plant in the north-eastern English city of Sunderland, where it employs some 7,000 
people. "With X-Trail already manufactured in Japan, we can reduce our upfront investment costs," said Gianluca 
de Ficchy, Nissan Europe chairman. "We appreciate this will be disappointing for our UK team and partners," de 
Ficchy added. "While we have taken this decision for business reasons, the continued uncertainty around the UK's 
future relationship with the EU is not helping companies like ours to plan for the future," he said.
----------
US President Donald Trump said Friday that negotiations with opposition Democrats over funding a border wall with 
Mexico have not advanced and that he may declare a national emergency in order to bypass Congress to build the 
barrier. "We're getting nowhere with the Democrats," Trump told reporters at the White House. "I think there's a 
good chance that we'll have to do that," he added, referring to declaring a national emergency. Trump did not 
definitely state whether he would declare a national emergency, which would enable him to fund a border wall 
without congressional approval but would certainly face legal challenges. Trump has agreed to open the 
government for three weeks, until February 15, to allow for negotiations with Democrats after a 35-day partial 
government shutdown, the longest in US history.
----------
China has called on Washington and Moscow to solve their differences related to the Intermediate-Range Nuclear 
Forces Treaty. "The Chinese side opposes the US withdrawal and urges the US and Russia to properly resolve 
their differences through constructive dialogue," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said on 
Saturday. Meanwhile, President Vladimir Putin said on Saturday that Russia will withdraw from the INF treaty, after 
the US announced that it was withdrawing from the agreement. The US said on Friday that it was withdrawing from 
the treaty with Russia, which dates to the waning years of the Cold War, amid accusations that Moscow is in 
violation of the deal.

Drugmaker Indivior said it has agreed to divest its interest related to the Sai Bo Song drug in China to Zhejiang 
Pukang Biotechnology for USD122.5 million. "The divestiture of the Sai Bo Song tablet in China is consistent with 
Indivior's efforts to prioritize efforts on the long-term growth opportunities with our new depot assets, Sublocade and 
Perseris," said Shaun Thaxter, chief executive officer of Indivior. "This transaction helps us focus our resources on 
the highest return opportunities in the regions we know best, while ensuring patients in China have access to an 
important and transformational treatment." Indivior also said it has signed an agreement with Alvogen Pine Brook 
prohibiting the US pharmaceutical company from distributing or selling its generic buprenorphine and naloxone 
sublingual film product in the US. Indivior had been granted a temporary restraining order by the US District Court 
for the District of New Jersey against Alvogen on January 24.
----------
Outsourcer Serco Group said it signed a GBP560 million contract with Bupa Health Services to support the 
Australian Defence Force. The contract has up to four one-year extensions and full operational service under the 
new contract will begin on July 1. Under the contract, Serco will be responsible for providing defence support 
services across more than 50 bases in Australia. Serco will be delivering recruitment, on-boarding, training, 
workforce management and various other employee lifecycle, account management and support functions.
----------
Wizz Air reported its January load factor improved by 0.4 percentage point to 88.1% and passenger numbers rose 
8.3% to 2.6 million from 2.4 million last year. The central and eastern Europe-focused airline said it expanded its 
network in January with an additional 14 routes announced in Macedonia, Romania and Albania.
----------
Metro Bank faces an investor lawsuit after the retail bank's disclosure of an accounting error wiped GBP1 billion of 
its market capitalisation, the Daily Mail reported. The newspaper said Metro Bank is being targeted by Therium, 
which funds major lawsuits by investors. On Thursday last week, Metro Bank confirmed it was UK regulators who 
initially uncovered irregularities in the lender's loan book and not the company itself. Shares in the FTSE 250-listed 
bank have dropped 46% since Wednesday, January 23, when it revealed the accounting error. The company's 
market cap now stands at GBP1.17 billion.
----------
COMPANIES - OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM
----------
Interserve is closing in on a rescue deal to swap almost a half of its debt for shares in the company, Sky News 
reported. The news website said the outsourcing firm could announce as soon as this week that it has reached an 
in-principle agreement with lenders about the restructuring. The debt-for-equity swap, which has been under 
discussion for several months, is likely to involve swapping around GBP300 million of its borrowings for new shares, 
according to Sky. At the end of December, Interserve confirmed talks to swap debt for equity and said it expected to 
end 2018 with between GBP625 million and GBP650 million in net debt. At the time, the company said it would 
publish the final form of the plan in early 2019.

COMPANIES - OTHER
----------
City broker Daniel Stewart has stopped taking on new clients, according to a notice on its website Friday. Daniel 
Stewart's website is blank other than the statement: "Please be aware that as a result of internal restructuring 
Daniel Stewart & Company PLC will not be accepting any new client instructions for the foreseeable future." The 
Evening Standard reported "it is understood" that "scores of staff" at the firm were made redundant at a meeting 
Thursday afternoon after Epsilon Investments, a Singaporean investment firm who had financially backed the 
broker, decided to pull the plug.

EXTRA: Ryanair Swings To Loss On Lower Fares, Plans Restructuring
EXTRA: Ryanair Swings To Loss On Lower Fares, Plans Restructuring
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 09:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 950 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Ryanair Holdings PLC on Monday said it will make changes to its corporate structure 
after swinging to a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit.
The stock was down 4.5% early Monday at EUR10.925. Ryanair shares have lost 32% of their value over the past 
12 months.
The Irish budget airline said that over the next 12 months it will move to a group structure not dissimilar to that of 
rival International Consolidated Airlines Group PLC, owner of British Airways and Spain's Iberia.
Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team will oversee the development of four airline 
subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK. 
The company said it believes the changes to its structure to be necessary to deliver cost and operating efficiencies 
as well as "enabling the group to look at other small scale merger and acquisition opportunities".
Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. O'Leary 
committed to further five years at the head of the company.
Ryanair will, later this year, appoint a replacement as CEO of Ryanair DAC, it said. DAC stands for designated 
activity company and is the company's main operating unit.
Chair David Bonderman and Senior Independent Director Kyran McLaughlin have agreed to remain on the 
company's board until summer 2020. They will leave after that date.
"In order to ensure a smooth succession, Stan McCarthy who joined the board in May 2017, has agreed to take up 
the position of deputy chair from April 2019, and will transition to chair of the board in summer 2020," Ryanair 
added.
EXTRA: Ryanair Swings To Loss On Lower Fares, Plans Restructuring
Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter results to the end of 2018 were "disappointing", with the group swinging 
to a EUR83.6 million pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago.
The results included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting mostly from the acquisition of Austrian airline Lauda. 
Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair still reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss versus a EUR126.0 million profit a 
year before.
Ryanair bought a 75% stake in the Austrian carrier, founded by former Formula One racer Niki Lauda, in July after 
the takeover was cleared by EU competition authorities. In December, Ryanair upped its interest in Lauda to 100%. 
The company now expects Lauda to record EUR140 million of exceptional year-one start-up loss due to the "very 
late" release of schedules, low promotional fares, expensive aircraft leases and unhedged fuel.
For its second year, Ryanair is guiding for a loss from Lauda of between EUR50 million and breakeven, depending 
on peak season yields. 
Meanwhile, Ryanair as a whole reported a 9% increase in revenue in the third quarter to EUR1.53 billion from 
EUR1.41 billion on the back of higher customer numbers, up to 32.7 million from 30.4 million a year ago.
O'Leary said: "While a EUR20 million loss in the third was disappointing, we take comfort that this was entirely due 
to weaker than expected air fares so our customers are enjoying record low prices, which is good for current and 
future traffic growth."
Ryanair load factor, in the third quarter, was unchanged compared to the prior year at 96%.
Looking ahead, Ryanair said that, excluding the expected "heavy" loss from Lauda in its first year of operations, its 
annual profit will come in between EUR1.0 billion and EUR1.1 billion due to lower winter fares but better-than-
expected cost performance in the second half.
A year ago, Ryanair profit was EUR1.45 billion, so the decline will be as much as 31%. 
"While we have reasonable visibility of our fourth quarter bookings, we cannot rule out further cuts to air fares 
and/or slightly lower full year guidance especially if there are unexpected Brexit and/or security developments which 
adversely impact fares for close-in bookings between now and the end of March," Ryanair said in its statement 
Monday.
"We do not share the recent optimistic outlook of some competitors that Summer 2019 airfares will rise. In the 
absence of further EU airline failures, and because of the recent fall in oil prices  we expect excess short haul 
capacity to continue through 2019, which will we believe lead to a weaker – not stronger – fare environment," it 
continued.
For January, the airline reported Monday that passenger numbers rose 11% to 10.3 million from 9.3 million a year 
prior, with Laudamotion contributing 300,000 new customers. 
On a rolling annual basis, Ryanair passengers in January were up 8% to 140.2 million from 129.4 million. 
During the first month of its fourth quarter, the company operated over 58,000 flights, with more than 90% arriving 
on time, excluding the delays due to air traffic control strikes, it said. 
In the past year, Ryanair suffered from prolonged strike action from both air traffic control workers and its own pilots 
and cabin crew members. 
Following the summer of strikes, Ryanair was able to sign deals with several unions across its international 
operations putting an end to the disruptions. 
EXTRA: Ryanair Swings To Loss On Lower Fares, Plans Restructuring
With regards to Brexit, Ryanair which had previously warned on the "underestimated" risk of a no-deal, said it has 
taken all the "necessary steps" to protect the company in that event. 
"We have now obtained a UK AOC to protect our 3 domestic UK routes, and we will place restrictions on the voting 
rights and share sales of non-EU shareholders for a period of time, in the event of a hard Brexit, to ensure that 
Ryanair remains at all times an EU owned and EU controlled airline, even if the UK exits the EU without a deal," the 
company explained.
By Elena Cherubini; elenacherubini@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 4, 2019
End of Document
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair To Reorganise As It Reports Quarterly Loss
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair To Reorganise As It Reports Quarterly Loss
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 11:14 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1515 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following is a summary of top news stories Monday.
----------
COMPANIES
----------
Ryanair Holdings said it will make changes to its corporate structure after swinging to a third-quarter loss and 
warning of lower annual profit. Under the proposed changes, a small senior management team will oversee the 
development of four airline subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and Ryanair UK. Chief Executive 
Officer Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. O'Leary committed to further 
five years at the head of the company. The airline said its third-quarter results to the end of 2018 were 
"disappointing", with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 million pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the 
comparative period a year ago. The results included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting mostly from the acquisition of 
Austrian airline Lauda. Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair still reported a EUR6.5 million operating loss versus a 
EUR126.0 million profit a year before.
----------
Indivior said it will divest its interest related to the Sai Bo Song tablet in China to Zhejiang Pukang Biotechnology for 
a maximum of USD122.5 million. Furthermore, the FTSE 250 drugmaker said it has entered into a deal with 
Alvogen Pine Brook restricting it from selling in the US its generic buprenorphine and naloxone sublingual film 
products, competing with Indivior's opioid addiction treatment Suboxone. Suboxone accounts for around 80% of 
Indivior's revenue. Indivior had been granted a temporary restraining order by the US District Court for the District of 
New Jersey against Alvogen on January 24. The order will will remain in place until February 7, when a preliminary 
injunction hearing will take place.
----------
Ferrexpo said it is conducting a comprehensive review of funds paid to a Ukrainian charity as part of its corporate 
social responsibility programme, after uncovering issues with the charity's accounts. The iron pellet producer 
explained its auditor Deloitte has received bank statements directly from the charity Blooming Land in order to verify 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair To Reorganise As It Reports Quarterly Loss
the use of contributions by Ferrexpo. The bank statements from the charity - which is entirely separately managed 
from Ferrexpo - revealed "as yet unexplained discrepancies". Consequently, Ferrexpo said it has decided to 
undertake a "comprehensive independent review" and is currently scoping the work. In the first half of 2018, 
Ferrexpo had contributed USD9.5 million to the medical and social services charity. It has not made any further 
donations since May 2018.
----------
Flybe Group confirmed it received a tentative proposal from former Stobart Group boss Andrew Tinkler, who offered 
a capital injection to the airline if its takeover by Connect Airways does not proceed. Flybe said that Tinkler made a 
"very preliminary, short and highly conditional outline contingency proposal" for a capital injection into the company, 
which would only take place if the sale of Flybe's operating business to Connect Airways were to be stopped. The 
proposal wasn't an offer for the entire company, Flybe said. However, the struggling airline said it "does not 
consider that the preliminary proposal offers the certainty required to secure the future of Flybe". "Accordingly, the 
board emphasizes to shareholders that it continues to regard the arrangements entered into with Connect Airways 
as being the only viable option available to the company which provides the security that the business needs to 
continue to trade successfully," Flybe said. Connect Airways is a joint venture among Stobart, Virgin Atlantic, and 
DLP Holdings, which agreed to acquire Flybe for 1 pence per share earlier in January.
----------
MARKETS
----------
Stocks in London were marginally higher amid low volatility as financial markets in China were closed for the Lunar 
New Year holiday. The pound was down against the dollar after a sharp decline in UK construction PMI. Wall Street 
was pointed to a higher open with Google parent Alphabet set to report earnings after the market close in New 
York. 
----------
FTSE 100: up 0.2% at 7,033.89
FTSE 250: up 0.1% at 18,829.55
AIM ALL-SHARE: flat at 921.77
GBP: down at USD1.3055 (USD1.3099)
EUR: down at USD1.1444 (USD1.1475)
GOLD: down at USD1,310.70 per ounce (USD1,316.80)
OIL (Brent): up at USD63.40 a barrel (USD61.90)
(changes since previous London equities close)
----------
ECONOMICS AND GENERAL
----------
Construction sector activity in the UK fell in January to its weakest level for ten months, the latest survey by IHS 
Markit showed. The UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index reading came in at 50.6 in January, down from 
52.8 recorded in December and missing consensus estimates of a score of 52.4. A PMI reading above 50 still 
suggests growth in the sector, however. The index posted above the 50-point no-change mark in each month since 
the snow-related decline seen in March 2018, but the latest expansion was the weakest seen over that ten-month 
period of growth, according to IHS Markit. IHS Markit highlighted that a number of survey respondents noted that 
Brexit uncertainty had led to hesitancy among clients and a corresponding slowdown in progress on new projects.
----------
UK Prime Minister Theresa May will invite rebel Tory members of Parliament into the heart of government on 
Monday to thrash out changes to her Brexit deal she hopes can overcome massive opposition in Brussels and 
Westminster. Hardline eurosceptics in the European Research Group and Remain-supporting former ministers will 
form the Alternative Arrangements Working Group, which Downing Street said would meet "regularly" with Brexit 
Secretary Stephen Barclay and senior officials. ERG deputy chairman Steve Baker, former Northern Ireland 
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: Ryanair To Reorganise As It Reports Quarterly Loss
secretary Owen Paterson and Yeovil MP Marcus Fysh will join forces with former education secretary Nicky Morgan 
and ex-cabinet office minister Damian Green to examine the feasibility of the so-called Malthouse Compromise.
----------
Industrial producer prices in the Eurozone fell month over month in December, while their annual rate of increase 
slowed by a full percentage point, according to data released by Eurostat. Industrial producer prices fell by 0.8% in 
December after the decrease of 0.3% registered in November. Year over year, prices rose by 3.0%, slowing from 
an annual increase of 4.0% the month before. The euro area producer price index fell 2.6% month-on-month in the 
energy sector and by 0.4% for intermediate goods, while prices remained stable for non-durable consumer goods 
and increased by 0.1% for capital goods and by 0.2% for durable consumer goods. Prices in total industry excluding 
energy fell by 0.1% on the month before.
----------
Japanese car maker Nissan Motor said it plans to switch production of a new SUV model from Britain to Japan, 
dealing another blow to the British government's post-Brexit economic plans. Nissan said it cancelled plans to 
produce the X-Trail model at its plant in the north-eastern English city of Sunderland, where it employs some 7,000 
people. "With X-Trail already manufactured in Japan, we can reduce our upfront investment costs," said Gianluca 
de Ficchy, Nissan Europe chairman. "We appreciate this will be disappointing for our UK team and partners," de 
Ficchy added. "While we have taken this decision for business reasons, the continued uncertainty around the UK's 
future relationship with the EU is not helping companies like ours to plan for the future," he said.
----------
US President Donald Trump said Friday that negotiations with opposition Democrats over funding a border wall with 
Mexico have not advanced and that he may declare a national emergency in order to bypass Congress to build the 
barrier. "We're getting nowhere with the Democrats," Trump told reporters at the White House. "I think there's a 
good chance that we'll have to do that," he added, referring to declaring a national emergency. Trump did not 
definitely state whether he would declare a national emergency, which would enable him to fund a border wall 
without congressional approval but would certainly face legal challenges. Trump has agreed to open the 
government for three weeks, until February 15, to allow for negotiations with Democrats after a 35-day partial 
government shutdown, the longest in US history.
----------
China has called on Washington and Moscow to solve their differences related to the Intermediate-Range Nuclear 
Forces Treaty. "The Chinese side opposes the US withdrawal and urges the US and Russia to properly resolve 
their differences through constructive dialogue," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said on 
Saturday. Meanwhile, President Vladimir Putin said on Saturday that Russia will withdraw from the INF treaty, after 
the US announced that it was withdrawing from the agreement. The US said on Friday that it was withdrawing from 
the treaty with Russia, which dates to the waning years of the Cold War, amid accusations that Moscow is in 
violation of the deal.
----------
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 4, 2019
End of Document
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Pulls Down easyJet, IAG After Loss
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Pulls Down easyJet, IAG After 
Loss
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 10:50 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 828 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - The following stocks are the leading risers and fallers within the main London indices 
on Monday.
----------
FTSE 100 - WINNERS
----------
WM Morrison Supermarkets, up 1.7%. The supermarket chain was raised to Neutral from Sell by Citigroup.
----------
FTSE 100 - LOSERS
----------
Fresnillo, down 2.0%. The gold miner was tracking spot gold prices lower, quoted at USD1,310.88 an ounce from 
USD1,316.80 at the London equities close Friday. The precious metal was retreating from eight-months high 
reached last week as the demand for safe-haven assets waned. 
----------
BHP Group, down 1.4%. JPMorgan downgraded the Anglo-Australian miner to Underweight from Neutral. 
----------
FTSE 250 - WINNERS
----------
William Hill, up 1.5%. Jefferies started coverage on the bookmaker with a Buy rating. 
----------
FTSE 250 - LOSERS
----------
Ferrexpo, down 9.7%. The iron ore pellet producer said it is conducting a comprehensive review of funds paid to a 
Ukrainian charity as part of its corporate social responsibility programme, after uncovering issues with the charity's 
accounts. Ferrexpo explained its auditor Deloitte has received bank statements directly from the charity Blooming 
WINNERS & LOSERS SUMMARY: Ryanair Pulls Down easyJet, IAG After Loss
Land in order to verify the use of contributions by Ferrexpo. The bank statements from the charity - which is entirely 
separately managed from Ferrexpo - revealed "as yet unexplained discrepancies". Consequently, Ferrexpo said it 
has decided to undertake a "comprehensive independent review" and is currently scoping the work. In the first half 
of 2018, Ferrexpo had contributed USD9.5 million to the medical and social services charity. It has not made any 
further donations since May 2018
----------
KAZ Minerals, down 2.5%. HSBC downgraded the miner to Hold from Buy. 
----------
OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM - WINNERS
----------
RPS Group, up 8.8%. The technical consultancy firm acquired Australian consultancy firm Corview for GBP18 
million and 2018 trading had been in line with market expectations. RPS will buy transport advisory firm Corview for 
a maximum consideration of AUD32.0 million - or GBP17.8 million - in cash. Of this, RPS will pay an initial AUD17.6 
million on completion with further payments of AUD4.8 million on the first, second and third anniversaries of 
completion. In 2018, RPS explained trading had been "in line" with market expectations. The firm expects adjusted 
pretax profit to be GBP50.2 million. Conversion of profit into operating cash flow was described as being "strong". 
Consequently, net debt fell to GBP73.9 million at the end of 2018 compared to GBP80.6 million the year prior. 
----------
Kainos Group, up 5.2%. The IT, consulting and software services firm said it expects its annual results to be "ahead 
of current market expectations" as it continued to see "very strong momentum". For the financial year ending 
March, the company's board guided for results beating market views as all its core markets operations reported 
growth so far. In financial 2018, Kainos recorded GBP14.3 million in pretax profit on revenue of GBP96.7 million. In 
the first half of the current year, the company recorded pretax profit of GBP8.7 million on revenue of GBP67.2 
million.
----------
OTHER MAIN MARKET AND AIM - LOSERS
----------
Ryanair Holdings, down 4.7%. The Irish carrier said it will make changes to its corporate structure after swinging to 
a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit. Under the proposed changes, a small senior management 
team will oversee the development of four airline subsidiaries, Ryanair DAC, Laudamotion, Ryanair Sun and 
Ryanair UK. Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary will become group CEO, leading all the units, the airline said. 
O'Leary committed to further five years at the head of the company. Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter 
results to the end of 2018 were "disappointing", with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 million pretax loss from a 
EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago. The results included a EUR61.5 million loss resulting 
mostly from the acquisition of Austrian airline Lauda. Excluding Lauda losses, Ryanair still reported a EUR6.5 
million operating loss versus a EUR126.0 million profit a year before. Peers easyJet and International Consolidated 
Airlines were down 1.4% and 0.5%, respectively. 
----------
Angus Energy, down 21%. The oil and gas company reported water intrusion during a test of its Brockham X4Z 
well. Angus, the operator of the licence, said the well has been perforated from 960 metres to 1,155 metres 
measured depth and produced in total 280 barrels. However, Angus said that "it has become apparent that a part of 
the perforated interval is producing water", which is inhibiting significant oil flow and therefore has not allowed for 
sustainable flow rates of oil. The firm is now looking to isolate the water zone. 
----------
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: February 4, 2019
End of Document
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Stocks Edge Higher; Ryanair Sounds Brexit Alarm
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Stocks Edge Higher; Ryanair Sounds Brexit Alarm
Alliance News
February 4, 2019 Monday 08:52 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 1095 words
Body
LONDON (Alliance News) - Stock prices in London opened marginally higher on Monday after quiet trading in Asia 
overnight, while Ryanair fell after posting a loss in the third quarter and issuing a strident warning about Brexit. 
The FTSE 100 index was up 11.15 points, or 0.2%, at 7,031.37 in early trade. The FTSE 250 was 17.12 points 
higher, or 0.1%, at 18,828.49. The AIM All-Share was flat at 921.42.
The Cboe UK 100 was up 0.2% at 11,941.96, while the Cboe UK 250 was up 0.1% at 16,815.87. The Cboe UK 
Small Companies also was up 0.1%, at 11,287.85.
In mainland Europe, the CAC 40 in Paris and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt were down 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. 
On the London Stock Exchange, GVC Holdings was the best blue-chip performer, up 1.8% after Jefferies started 
coverage on the sports betting and gaming company with a Buy rating.
WM Morrison Supermarkets was up 1.3% after Citigroup raised the supermarket chain to Neutral from Sell.
At the other end of the large cap index, miners were lower. Rio Tinto was down 1.3%, Glencore down 0.9%, 
Antofagasta down 1.0% and Anglo American down 0.7%. BHP Group was off 1.2% after being cut to Underweight 
from Neutral by JPMorgan. 
"Despite positive developments on the trade front, with US and China resuming dialogue, slowing Chinese demand 
appears to have taken its toll on the region and remains a cause of concern going forward," said analysts at Oxford 
Economics.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Stocks Edge Higher; Ryanair Sounds Brexit Alarm
Chinese manufacturing activity shrunk to a nearly three-year low in January as underlying trends in production 
weakened and export sales increased, according to a report that was released on Friday. Survey data from IHS 
Markit showed the headline seasonally adjusted Caixin Factory Purchasing Managers' Index, or PMI, fell to 48.3 
from 49.7 in December. The reading was the lowest since February 2016. Any reading below 50 suggests 
contraction in the sector.
In the FTSE 250, William Hill was up 3.3% on Monday, after Jefferies started coverage on the bookmaker with a 
Buy rating and Shore Capital raised the stock to Buy from Hold. 
At the other end of the midcap index, Ferrexpo was the worst performer, down 6.0% after the iron pellet producer 
said it is conducting a comprehensive review of funds paid to a Ukrainian charity as part of its corporate social 
responsibility programme, after uncovering issues with the charity's accounts.
Ferrexpo explained its auditor Deloitte has received bank statements directly from the charity Blooming Land in 
order to verify the use of contributions by Ferrexpo.
The bank statements from the charity - which is entirely separately managed from Ferrexpo - revealed "as yet 
unexplained discrepancies". Consequently, Ferrexpo said it has decided to undertake a "comprehensive 
independent review" and is currently scoping the work.
In the first half of 2018, Ferrexpo had contributed USD9.5 million to the medical and social services charity. It has 
not made any further donations since May 2018.
Elsewhere, Ryanair Holdings was down 3.8%. The budget airline said it will make changes to its corporate structure 
after swinging to a third-quarter loss and warning of lower annual profit.
The Irish airline said that over the next 12 months it will move to a group structure not dissimilar to that of rival 
International Consolidated Airlines Group, owner of British Airways and Spain's Iberia.
Meanwhile, the airline said its third-quarter results were disappointing, with the group swinging to a EUR83.6 million 
pretax loss from a EUR112.9 million profit in the comparative period a year ago.
In addition, Ryanair also raised concerns over the UK crashing out of the European Union without a trade deal. 
"The risk of a no deal Brexit remains worryingly high. While we hope that common sense will prevail, and lead to 
either a delay in Brexit, or agreement on the 21 month transition deal currently on the table, we have taken all 
necessary steps to protect Ryanair's business in a no-deal environment. We have now obtained a UK AOC to 
protect our 3 domestic UK routes, and we will place restrictions on the voting rights and share sales of non-EU 
shareholders for a period of time to ensure that Ryanair remains at all times an EU owned and EU controlled airline, 
even if the UK exits the EU without a deal," said Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary. 
Peer easyJet was the worst performer in the FTSE 100, down 1.9%. 
The Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.5% while the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong closed up 0.2%. 
Financial markets in China are closed on Monday for Chinese New Year's Eve and will remain closed for the rest of 
the week for Chinese New Year. 
Hong Kong's financial markets were open for a half day on Monday and will be closed Tuesday to Thursday for the 
Lunar New Year holiday. The Hang Seng index ended Monday up 0.2%.
The pound was marginally lower, quoted at USD1.3084 early Monday from USD1.3099 at the London equities 
close Friday.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Stocks Edge Higher; Ryanair Sounds Brexit Alarm
UK Prime Minister Theresa May will invite rebel Tory members of Parliament into the heart of government on 
Monday to thrash out changes to her Brexit deal she hopes can overcome massive opposition in Brussels and 
Westminster.
Hardline eurosceptics in the European Research Group and Remain-supporting former ministers will form the 
Alternative Arrangements Working Group, which Downing Street said would meet "regularly" with Brexit Secretary 
Stephen Barclay and senior officials.
ERG deputy chairman Steve Baker, former Northern Ireland secretary Owen Paterson and Yeovil MP Marcus Fysh 
will join forces with former education secretary Nicky Morgan and ex-cabinet office minister Damian Green to 
examine the feasibility of the so-called Malthouse Compromise.
"There still appears little chance of the EU budging from its refusal to reopen the withdrawal agreement to drop the 
Irish border backstop. But the Political Declaration remains open for modification. And with the Government offering 
Labour MPs financial inducements to benefit their constituencies, and conducting discussions on safeguards and 
possible enhancements to workers' rights, there remains the possibility that a majority in Parliament could 
eventually be found for a deliverable Brexit," said analysts at Daiwa Capital Markets. 
The economic events calendar has UK construction PMI at 0930 GMT. There also are Italy inflation readings and 
eurozone producer prices at 1000 GMT. 
In the US earnings calendar on Monday, Google parent Alphabet will report earnings after the market close in New 
York. 
By Arvind Bhunjun; arvindbhunjun@alliancenews.com
